was equivalent to finding the Rosetta Stone.”
Hamish and Jesse flipped through the pages the
rest of the afternoon, mesmerized, then began to
hatch an idea: What if they could share this with their

friends? They photographed each page and put the
whole thing online at www.standardsmanual.com and
sent it around to a few friends and colleagues who
they figured would love to nerd out like they had. (The
site has since been updated—more on that later.)
They completely underestimated how many people
would be into it. Within a few days, the site had
250,000 views. They later got some press, too—a
couple of articles and some interviews. “This would
make a great book,” they thought. But how would
they make it? And what about the copyright? The
excitement died down, other things took their
attention away from the manual, and that big red
binder sat on a shelf waiting.

A VIRAL SUCCESS
Hamish and I met at a party in the spring of 2014, just
a week after the Neil Young PonoPlayer campaign
wrapped and a couple of years after the discovery of
the manual. I’d helped the Pono team raise over $6.2
million, and I had finally embraced being the
“Crowdsourceress” and started pursuing it as my
career.
At one point, everyone gathered together for a
toast. Hamish and I had never spoken to each other
before, but he locked eyes with me as we clinked
glasses and said, “Are you ready?” That was all it
took. We started talking and immediately hit it off.
We’ve been collaborating (and dating) ever since.
(You’ll hear about our work together in several places
throughout this book.)
Not long after we met, Hamish told me the story of
how he found the NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
(what we simply called the “Standards Manual” or the
“NYCTA manual”). He was still giddy about finding it,
even though it was some two years later. I thought it
was really cool, but as I wasn’t a designer—I didn’t
fully understand the freak-out factor of this geeky
piece of history. And of course I had no idea that this
binder would lead to one of my most successful
crowdfunding projects to date.
But then Hamish told me what happened when he
and Jesse photographed it and put it online.

“Did you say a quarter of a million people checked
out the site? In just a few days? For a book about
subway signs?” I asked.
He nodded.
“We also got press in Gizmodo and Under
Consideration, and a bunch of people were tweeting
about it,” he told me.
Then my brain clicked into gear. “Have you ever
thought about doing a Kickstarter?”
Once I heard about what a viral success the website
had been, I immediately saw huge potential in the
manual. This binder full of fonts and colors had
something that could propel it to crowdfunding
success: a built-in audience. In the same way WFMU
fans had so eagerly supported Tim’s Sex and
Broadcasting documentary, an enthusiastic
community of designers would rally around this
project.
Before I got too pumped up about taking the manual
to Kickstarter, Hamish pointed out an issue that could
potentially stop us in our tracks: The copyright was
retained by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority
(MTA). Hamish thought it all seemed too hard to pull
off, plus he and Jesse had demanding full-time jobs at
Pentagram.
But I was determined. “How can we get this in
front of the MTA?” I asked.
“Well come to think of it, MTA is now a Pentagram
client,” he said.
“Then could you just ask the MTA about reissuing
the manual?”

He did. And after a few meetings, the MTA gave us
the okay and prepared an agreement. I have a feeling
they had the exact same reaction I did when I first
talked to Hamish about the manual. Is anyone really
interested in an out-of-print binder about subway
signage?

BUILDING THE BOOK
With approval from the MTA, there was nothing
stopping us: Jesse, Hamish, and I began preparing a
Kickstarter campaign to crowdfund a reissue of the
Standards Manual.
Our goal was to reissue the Standards Manual as a
full-size, high-quality hardcover book. Knowing our
audience would likely be mostly designers, we
recognized that one of our biggest strengths would be
the book itself. We set out to make sure the
reproduced version of the manual would be visually
stunning—a collector’s item that our audience would
find incredible.
In addition to ensuring the book itself was beautiful
and well made, as part of the reissue, we wanted to
add a foreword and essay to set the tone of the book
and add to its appeal. One of Jesse’s contacts
recommended New York magazine writer Christopher
Bonanos as someone knowledgeable and passionate
about NYC, transit, and design. When Hamish and
Jesse brought the idea to Chris, he said, “I was meant
to write this.” We hired Chris to write a 6,000-plus-
word essay on the history of the Standards Manual,
which included interviewing people who worked on
the successors to the Standards Manual and MTA
staff—all original insider knowledge our designer
audience would be excited to get their hands on.

In Conversation with Hamish Smyth: Designing and
Budgeting for the NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
Reissue
Hamish, being a designer himself, had a ton of
knowledge about the nuts and bolts of creating
this beautiful package. I spoke to him about the
process.
Dreaming Up the Book
The size of the sheets in the original Standards
Manual binder was 13" by 13" and we wanted to
maintain that size. From our experience designing
and producing book and print projects at
Pentagram, we thought a four-color job would do
the trick. We also wanted our book to have a
cloth cover, and be all around high quality. Those
were our starting points.
Finding a Printer
We talked to about fifteen printers before
choosing an Italian printer who specialized in high-
quality art books who could bind the size book we
wanted to make.
Designing the Book and Considering Costs
Based on conversations with friends in the
industry, Jesse and I figured that if you found a
book like this in the bookstore, you might pay up
to $150 for it, but on Kickstarter, we thought

people wouldn’t want to pay more than about
$100. This was our first time doing a project like
this, so we didn’t have a track record with
potential backers. Plus, backers wouldn’t be able
to see and feel the quality of the book as they
would if they were in a store.
We met with a representative from the printer,
and she brought some sample books with her as
well as paper types so we could see what we
could get for our money. We told her what we
liked, and then she followed up by sending us a
detailed estimate with a number of quality and
cost options.
The printer gave us quotes for how much it
would cost to print 500, 1,000, 2,000, and 5,000
books. As the quantity goes up, cost per copy
comes down. They also said they could package
the books in custom cardboard boxes, adding
about 50 cents to the production cost of each
book.
To design the book the way we wanted to, the
cost of producing each unit was coming out at
around $98.
Planning to Ship
The printer sent us a blank dummy copy so we
could make sure we were happy with the weight,
paper, and cover material. We weighed it so we
could start estimating shipping costs. We got
connected to a U.S.-based distribution company
and told them the size and weight of the book,

and they gave us an estimate of the costs to ship
to each worldwide destination.
The way Kickstarter is set up now, you can
easily transfer the shipping costs to backers, if
you want, by adding the shipping fees from your
distribution partner to Kickstarter in the back end
before launching, which is tacked on to the
backer’s pledge amount at check out.
Finalizing Costs
Our budget spreadsheet included the following
costs.
• Making the book
• Shipping the book
• Making the video, including original
music we commissioned
• Scanning the manual (Jesse and I
would do the layout)
• Paying the writers of the foreword and
introductory essay
• Fee for campaign management by Vann
Alexandra
• A tiny bit of buffer for unexpected costs
Then we considered taxes and fees, including
an import tax as well as a sea freight fare to get
the books from the Italian printer to the U.S.-
based fulfillment partner. We also factored in
Kickstarter’s payment and processing fees.

Setting and Reaching Our Goal
Producing 1,000 books would bring us to our
$108,000 goal, which would mean we would
barely scrape by. Thankfully, we surpassed our
goal, and as we sold more books and our unit
cost began to decrease, we were able to put the
additional money back into the book. We
introduced eight spot colors and upgraded to
Stochastic printing (to render details more clearly)
and hand-sewn bindings. We shared the
upgrades with the backer community, and
everyone loved it.
Hamish and Jesse approached Pentagram partner
Michael Bierut, their boss, to write the foreword.
Michael is a bona fide graphic design god, and before
joining Pentagram he worked for ten years under
Massimo Vignelli, one of the original creators of the
Standards Manual. (There is an entire generation of
current designers out there who fetishize Vignelli’s
work.) When Hamish and Jesse asked Michael if he
would be in our Kickstarter video, too, he said yes.
Including him in the book and campaign was key.
Hamish and Jesse were intent on finding an
excellent printer for the book, and after some research
and asking around, they found one they liked in Italy.
The pair had hoped to print in the U.S., but because of
the oversized binding of the book (13.5"), they were
unable to find a domestic printer with the hand-binding
capabilities needed. The plan was to scan each page

of the original binder, clean up the files in Photoshop,
arrange them in the book layout with the foreword and
essay, and send the final file to the printer, where the
books would be printed, bound, finished, and prepared
for shipping. For quality control, Hamish and Jesse
planned to preview the pages and a full sample
version of the book in advance (called a dummy), and
also check the sheets while being printed in Italy
(called a press check).
We carefully calculated what it would cost to scan,
print, and ship the books. After determining all the
book-related expenses, we also took into account the
Kickstarter processing fees, costs associated with
creating the campaign, and added a small buffer to
determine our final goal: $108,000. That amount
would allow us to print 1,000 books and (barely) cover
additional costs.

CAMPAIGN EXCLUSIVITY
Hamish, Jesse, and I took every step possible to
position the Standards Manual campaign as the
reissue of a beautiful, rare book that, before now,
designers never could have imagined owning
themselves. But a major condition of our contract with
MTA, it turned out, added a whole other level of
exclusivity (and desirability).
Here is how we described this on the Kickstarter
page:
In 2012—42 years after the Standards Manual
was released—we discovered a rare copy in the
basement of design firm Pentagram.
Now, under an agreement with the MTA, we
are scanning and printing every page in a full-size
hardcover book.
After this campaign, this reissue will never
become available again.
Part of our agreement with the MTA stipulated that
the reproduced manuals would be available only
during the length of our campaign. This condition
added a heightened sense of urgency to our project.
People interested in this book would have just 30 days
—the length of our Kickstarter campaign—to back our
project and obtain a book. After that, this special

reissue would not be available again.
I had never worked on something that was so
strictly exclusive to just the Kickstarter campaign
before. As the campaign progressed, I realized that
the urgency this created was a huge success factor.
When a product is available after a campaign ends,
people might not feel inclined to support it, but if it’s
clear that this is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, the
campaign has a great chance of taking off.

SOCIAL MEDIA AND PRESS STRATEGY
While Jesse and Hamish finalized logistics with the
printer, I got to work on my specialty: getting this
campaign ready to succeed. I knew we needed to rev
up our audience online with social media and press.
So, leading up to the Standards Manual campaign
launch, my colleague and I did the most extensive
campaign research we had done to date.
Because the project had already exploded
organically when the original website launched, we
figured the best approach was to first target this core
group of people that drove all that traffic. Basically, we
wanted to do everything we could to find those
250,000 people who had shown interest in Hamish
and Jesse’s website a couple of years before. They
were our built-in audience—we just needed to get our
project in front of them.
On top of that, we would expand our reach by
identifying influencers in the design community, as
well as other communities that would be interested in
the Standards Manual. Our goal was to get all these
people talking about the project on Launch Day so we
could pick up early momentum. We needed tweets,
shares, likes—you name it. The more buzz, the better.
We also worked to line up as much press coverage
as possible, researching and pitching publications and
blogs that would be into this. We were excited when
we locked in an exclusive for Launch Day (an article

that breaks the story): Steven Heller, with his popular
design blog on Print Magazine, agreed to run a story
online right after we kicked off the campaign
announcing promoting the launch.
The work we did paved the way for the kinds of
influencer and press strategies we do all the time at
Vann Alexandra today. Here is a run-down of how we
handled press and social media prep work, which is
still deeply embedded in our current outreach strategy
and can be adapted for almost any project. Since then,
we’ve created a scheduled system we use for each
campaign. You’ll read more about our timeline and
process in chapter 7. (There is a sample schedule in
the Resources section, too.)
SOCIAL MEDIA SET-UP AND PRESS RESEARCH
• We created a Twitter account for the
Standards Manual (@standardsmanual) and
asked friends and colleagues on Twitter to
follow and share the account.
• We created a social media strategy that
involved sharing a photo of the book every
day. We pre-uploaded each tweet so that
there was a consistent daily stream of
images. This strategy received press from
Fast Company even before our Kickstarter
launched.
• We reread the press around the website
launch in 2012 to understand the cult appeal
of the manual.

• We created a press database (a Google
spreadsheet) with the top names, emails,
and Twitter handles (and their follower
count) of the journalists that had written
about the Standards Manual or Massimo
Vignelli in the past couple of years.
• We made a press list of online publications
that might be interested in covering our
campaign and who would promote it to
audiences interested in the Standards
Manual (blogs about design, fashion, urban
design, subway enthusiasts, New York).

BUILDING OUT THE SOCIAL MEDIA DATABASE
We created a social media database (a second tab in
our press database sheet) and added the top
influencers who were tweeting and posting about the
Standards Manual during that time, including their
names, emails, Twitter handles and any other details
about what they posted. We also scoured the Internet
to find as many of the quarter of a million people who
hit the Standards Manual site in 2012 as possible. We
looked for anyone who had mentioned or shared
www.standardsmanual.com with thousands of
followers, for example.

IDENTIFYING INFLUENCERS
We put together a huge wish list within this social
media database, including designers who were recent
recipients of awards in the design community,
designers close to the campaign through Hamish and
Jesse’s connections, institutions that would be
interested, and other design influencers.

DIRECT OUTREACH INVITING PEOPLE TO SHARE AND BACK
OUR CAMPAIGN
As we got closer to the campaign launch, we emailed
the people in our social media and press databases.
We tried to be as personal as possible, sending
screenshots of tweets they had posted in support of
the manual with something like: “We saw that you
tweeted about the Standards Manual and thought you
would be interested to know about an exciting project
around its reissue.” We asked them if they’d be
willing to support our campaign by posting about it on
Launch Day, hoping they’d back us, too. As our launch
approached, we also did the following:
• We continued to send a ton of emails, all
personalized with either a screenshot of a
tweet about the Standards Manual,
individualized notes about the person’s
relationship with Hamish or Jesse, or notes
about their publicly proven interest in the
Standards Manual (from blog posts or social
shares we found).
• We created a press release and press kit
and repitched the press database with a
follow-up. This is when Steven Heller
agreed to write about the story.
• We sent sample tweets to every single
influencer so that they could all tweet at the

same time on Launch Day:
I just backed the full-size reissue of the
NYCTA @standardsmanual #boom
http://kck.st/1uFblmV
• We shared the campaign preview link along
with high-resolution images to a select
handful of press contacts. The preview link
is a link you can grab from your campaign
account to share with people before the
campaign is launched. (We also used this
link when getting feedback about the
campaign page from a few colleagues and
advisors.)
• We emailed a trusted group of friends and
family about backing our project on Launch
Day.

Don’t Forget Your Family and Friends!
In addition to our social media and press
databases, Jesse, Hamish, and I also made a list
of all of our personal contacts—some designers,
some not. We wanted to rely on our close
contacts to secure early pledges for Launch Day
and help spread the word. I had learned from my
first campaign that securing momentum early on
Launch Day (and having money committed before
press starts driving more people to the page) is
essential to a project’s early success.

LAUNCH DAY
Launch Day was insane (hot tip: it always is). The
night before, we didn’t sleep at all because we were
still working on the video. Hamish found an error in
the title cards around 2:00 AM and needed to have the
editor go in and fix it. Then we needed to wake up at 6
AM to line up emails to send to friends and family as
soon as we launched.
First thing on Launch Day, we clicked “Launch” on
Kickstarter. Then we released a friends and family
newsletter with the campaign link so they could
submit their early donations. Our goal was to have at
least $2,000 pledged before Heller’s exclusive went
live and more eyes ended up on the page.
Within a couple hours of being live, we followed up
with our database of influencers and professional
contacts, again sending the campaign link and sample
tweet. Our press exclusive also went live. Once it was
up, we used it as evidence that our project was
getting talked about and started to pitch all the
publications we had originally pitched, as well as
others we researched. On social media, we posted
our campaign link.
All day, we responded to Kickstarter messages,
answered inbound press questions, and kept our eye
on Twitter. Nearing lunchtime, it was evident we were
headed toward rapid success. Our planning had paid
off in a big way. Press and social media were picking

up our campaign left and right.
Over the course of the campaign, numerous
influencers from around the world tweeted about the
project, including Pentagram, Kickstarter, AIGA,
designer Adrian Shaughnessy, type designers Tobias
Frere-Jones and Erik Spiekermann, and the London-
based design consultancy Wolff Olins.
Design press blogged about the project and shared
it on social media. We got attention from Print, Fast
Company, Gizmodo, Under Consideration, and tons
more.
The Kickstarter staff chose the Standards Manual
campaign as a Project We Love. Later in the
campaign, they also posted about it on social media
and included us in their big newsletter.
We hit our $108,000 goal by lunch. By the next day,
we raised $374,348 and were 346 percent funded
with 3,296 backers.
To say we were shocked would be an
understatement. We thought we’d sell 1,000 or so
books by the time the campaign ended—but we sold
nearly double that within a single day. It was clear that
this was a book designers desperately wanted to own.
By the end of our 30-day campaign, we raised
$802,812 from 6,718 backers. It closed 743 percent
funded.

THE TAKEAWAYS
The Standards Manual campaign is still one of my
favorites. It’s funny to think that it all started with a
binder hidden under gym clothes in a basement. It
took six months to scan, design, write, print, ship the
books from Italy, get them through customs, and then
process them for shipping to get the thousands of
books out the door (which is actually a very short turn-
around for the publishing industry). But it was worth
the wait: our backers loved them.
We tried out a lot of things and did a lot of them
right. We did everything we could to perfect the
design of the book itself, to make the campaign page
clear and strong, and to harness our built-in audience
—as well as penetrate an even broader audience—
through social media and press. We did three key
things that took it to the next level. First, we led with
design excellence. Before we launched the Standards
Manual campaign, I can honestly say I’d never seen a
crowdfunding campaign page with the level of
production value we achieved with this project. With
Jesse and Hamish’s insistence on design excellence
—from the book itself, to the video, to images of the
original manual and renderings of the book—the page
was gorgeous. Presentation is crucial! Second, we
leveraged the urgency. There’s something super
powerful in offering an exclusive, limited-edition,
Kickstarter-only product. It’s like a flash sale. Third, we

seized upon the power of crowdfunding vs. traditional
publishing. Independently producing the book allowed
us to closely control the production of the book,
distribute it quickly, and keep costs low. If we had
approached a traditional publisher about reprinting a
book that only designers would be interested in
buying, I have a feeling they would have thought our
audience was too niche, too small. But niche
audiences add up, especially when you can harness
them online.
PART II: THE NASA MANUAL EDITION

WE DID IT AGAIN, BUT BIGGER THIS TIME
Just months after the Standards Manual campaign
ended, one of the campaign’s backers tweeted an
idea for another reissue—this time for a much bigger,
much more well-known agency: NASA.
After the huge success of kickstarting the Standards
Manual, Jesse and Hamish had made a list of other
dream projects they wanted to do one day, and a
reissue of the NASA Graphics Standards Manual was
already on it. So when they saw that tweet, they got
validation for their idea directly from their built-in
audience.
Bringing together a community is one of the real
powers of crowdfunding. With the Standards Manual,
we could see a community forming during our
campaign—with the follows and tweets and
conversations online. It continued to be active after
the campaign ended as we shared updates through
Kickstarter, making sure we were communicative with
backers. We also made an effort to keep our
Standards Manual Twitter account active. People were
talking with each other and with us, and sharing
images of their lives and their new books. Here was a
community of people who might never have come
together had this project not existed.
With encouragement from our engaged community,
we also looked for a market test, one that would be
similar to the viral Standards Manual website. It turned

out that there was a Flickr page with photos of most
of the pages of the original NASA manual. When we
checked, we saw it had 120,000 views. That was a lot
of eyeballs.
So not all that long after the wrap of the first manual
reissue, we began planning the reissue of the NASA
Graphics Standards Manual, the campaign that, to me,
showed we could offer a radical alternative to the
book industry.

TAKING OUTREACH TO THE NEXT LEVEL
For the NASA manual, most of the process we
learned from our first rodeo with the Standards
Manual was repeated. That said, in the time since the
first Standards Manual, we’d gotten smarter with our
outreach.
We tightened up our email communication for
pitches. We made the emails more personal, making
sure to address recipients by name. Previously, we’d
sent pitches to “info” emails of design blogs (e.g.,
info@designblog.com). This time around, we made
sure to find individuals’ email addresses; plus, we had
contacts from press that had written about the first
campaign. We also tightened up our emails so the
pitch was much, much shorter—like four sentences.
And we made our subject lines short and to the point.
For our exclusive, we aimed high with the New York
Times. We contacted one reporter who we knew from
our research had written about space and NASA, and
we pitched him first. We told him he was the first to
hear about our campaign plan, and that the email was
confidential. This no doubt made it appealing to him.
That’s how we got our New York Times exclusive
lined up for Launch Day. (I’ll cover our whole press-
pitching strategy in chapter 7.)
We also worked hard on our social media campaign,
finding a ton of highly respected influencers (about
1,000) who we researched extensively. The list

included astronauts, artists focusing on space, science
nerds, designers that love space, and more. We
included influential backers, like journalists, from the
first Standards Manual project.
From our influencer list, we created a short list to
pitch before the campaign in order to line up Launch
Day buzz. For the remaining group, we drafted
personalized emails and saved them in our email
outboxes to send on Launch Day.
The night before launching, per usual, we didn’t
sleep. Launch Day was full of excitement and we
smashed through the $158,000 goal. That night,
Jesse, Hamish, and I met for celebratory drinks,
exhausted but thrilled. By the next day, we had raised
$344,394 from 3,400 backers. Our campaign went on
to raise $941,966 from 8,798 backers—that’s the
most successful graphic design project on Kickstarter
ever, followed closely by the NYCTA Graphics
Standards Manual. We had raised close to $1.8 million
within one year from over 15,500 backers for two
obsolete design manuals.

A NEW MODEL FOR THE BOOK INDUSTRY
If we could sell thousands of these design books and
make millions, why aren’t traditional publishers doing
the same thing?
Elaborate, high-quality books like these that appeal
to a small audience are likely risky for publishers. The
traditional publishing model requires that thousands of
books are printed in advance and shipped to
bookstores, where they sit and wait for an audience to
find them. Publishers probably don’t want to try to sell
8-pound books about logos because they have no
good way of producing them in a cost-effective
manner and efficiently connecting with the people
who will buy them.
Crowdfunding offers a way to fund the production
of your book and sell your book in a single process.
With crowdfunding, you can appeal directly to the
crowd. It allows you to leverage a platform such as
Kickstarter to find and connect to your audience,
create enthusiasm, make sales, and get the money
you need to create and distribute a beautiful product.
This means there’s an opportunity to skip the many
traditional gatekeepers along the way and create the
exact book you want.

Chapter 4
The Campaign Page Is Your
Pitch
The campaign page is where you get to explain and
present your project in full. And that doesn’t mean just
typing in a few paragraphs in the fields provided by
the crowdfunding platform. It means showing what
your campaign, your brand, and you are all about
through a narrative and visuals. It’s your story.
Your project page must be as professional as your
video. It’s critical to convey a consistent style across
your page and video—the same typography, brand
colors, graphic elements, and photo style. Your
campaign is a marketing tool—a platform for launching
your brand—so understanding your brand voice, style,
and identity is crucial to making your page successful.
More on that soon, and even more on design and
marketing through crowdfunding in the next chapter.

WRITING THE STORY
When my team and I sit down to put together a
campaign page, we first need to understand the story
we’re telling. Our goals are to be descriptive,
transparent, captivating, and persuasive. We have to
lead backers through our thinking, step by step, so by
the end, they can’t wait to back our project.
Often, the story on the page is similar to the story in
the video, but more robust. It’s actually okay if the
video story and page story overlap—some people
might scroll down and start reading before watching
the video, so your campaign page should start at the
beginning.
In the video, getting to the point of what your
project is in the first 30 seconds is important, and on
the page, we take a similar approach. Without wasting
any space, we want to quickly tell readers in plain,
simple terms exactly what this project is all about—
and get them intrigued, ready to scroll down to learn
more.
With the Standards Manual, for instance, we began
with a 45-word narrative in large header text to set the
stage of the project:
If you found yourself in the New York City
Subway in the 1960s, you were probably lost.
Signs didn’t help you find your way, standards
didn’t exist, even handmade lettering was

common. Mass confusion was the status quo.
In 1970, the Standards Manual changed
everything.
In just a few sentences, we hoped to grab readers’
attention. We wanted to create suspense and interest.
Then we offered the details in body text:
In 1967 the New York City Transit Authority hired
Massimo Vignelli and Bob Noorda of the design
firm Unimark International to design a signage
and wayfinding system that would solve the
problem underground.
The work they delivered, the 1970 New York
City Transit Authority Graphics Standards Manual,
succeeded in that goal and, perhaps
unintentionally, the Standards Manual became
one of the world’s classic examples of modern
design.
After that short intro come eight hi-res images of
the cover and the book so potential backers could see
exactly what we were describing. It’s important to
show readers what you’re talking about whenever
possible, and to break up paragraphs of text with
images.
What next? It depends on your story and audience.
With the Standards Manual, we included a strong
quote from a reputable editor/journalist, then
introduced another selling point: the fact that because

of the agreement with the MTA, the reissue would
never become available again.
We distilled our key takeaways into one-liners,
letting line breaks give the story room to breathe. It
made the page easy to scan and quickly digest. Then
we added nine more images, followed by
specifications, followed by another image. We knew
our audience of design nerds would want a super
clear understanding of why this book was going to be
awesome, so we were as direct as possible. From
there, we added plenty more images, along with
details about the introduction we were going to add
and the book’s high production value.
In case anyone was still on the fence at this point,
our next section, “Why is the Standards Manual worth
saving?” drove home our message and showed our
creators’ enthusiasm, along with the universality of its
appeal:
Every single day, millions of New Yorkers rely on
the subway to get around the city, and you can’t
use the subway without encountering the
signage designed by Unimark. Over the years
many changes have taken place (such as the
switch from Standard Medium to Helvetica), but it
is a testament to the quality of the work that, 44
years later, the signage holds up.
And perhaps on a deeper level, the signage has
given the subway a voice. When a lot of people
think of New York City, these signs pop into their
head. We feel a tremendous responsibility to

publish not only an important piece of design
history, but an important part of New York City’s
history.
Finally, we covered the last details in a few short
sections: “What are the differences between the
original and the reissue?,” “Why Kickstarter?,”
“Partnership with MTA and Goal,” “Quality,”
“Standard Medium Font Design,” and “Risks and
Challenges.” (Risks and Challenges is a Kickstarter
section, and one that’s mandatory for all projects.
More on that later.) We also added a section called
“Project Credits” so that readers could get more
information on the team behind the project.
I love the Standards Manual campaign page
because it’s at once a fascinating story and a visual
journey from the old manual to the new one. (The
campaign for the NASA manual does the same thing.)
It answers questions, covering the what, when, how,
why, and who about the project while never becoming
long-winded or dry. There are no chunky paragraphs,
the story flows quickly, with beautiful photographs
and renderings to show readers the product along the
way, and there are great moments of white space.
(Hamish and Jesse actually made these huge line
breaks by creating white blocks and inserting them as
images because they wanted to control the formatting
—genius. It’s worth pointing out that you can create
this white space on Indiegogo by hitting “Return.”)
It’s also a totally unique campaign page. That’s
because the story and the way we told it fit this

campaign. But it’s not a magic formula that will work
for others. Just as I said with the video, there’s no
standard page length or style that will lead to success.
Each project will be different.
The project page for our Kickstarter campaign for
Makerarm, for instance, looks very different from the
one we made for the Standards Manual. Makerarm,
which we worked on in 2015, is a beautifully designed
robotic arm that mounts to your desktop. Basically, it’s
a 20-inch-tall white cylindrical tube of metal with a
moveable arm extending from it. The arm can be fitted
with tons of exchangeable tool heads that can 3D
print, laser engrave, plot, mill, assemble electronics,
and do much more.
I’ll use Makerarm (a tech project) and the Standards
Manual (a graphic design project) to illustrate the
project page communication advice I offer my clients.

CREATE A CLEAR PROJECT TITLE AND BLURB
Choose a title that states and sells your project in one
line. In your title, answer the question What is this
project?
• Makerarm—The first robotic arm that makes
anything, anywhere
• The NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
reissue
Be clear. Use a keyword for the subject (the thing or
person) and a descriptive word for what it is (a robotic
arm, a reissue).
With the short blurb, you also have a limited number
of characters. Ask yourself: If I were to sell my project
in one punchy line, what would I say?
• Makerarm—The first robotic arm that makes
anything, anywhere: A complete digital
fabrication system for makers everywhere:
3D print, laser, carve, plot, assemble,
pick/place + more on your desktop!
• The NYCTA Graphics Standards Manual
reissue: Limited edition reissue of the 1970
New York City Transit Authority Graphics
Standards Manual, by Unimark’s Massimo

Vignelli and Bob Noorda. Exclusive to
Kickstarter.
Show what’s special about your project. Drop
names, show access and exclusivity. Note we used
words and phrases like “limited edition,” “exclusive,”
and “first.”

BEGIN WITH A STRONG INTRODUCTION
Introduce your project quickly and clearly at the top of
your page. This is the beginning of your story. Get
readers hooked so they’ll read more.
With Makerarm, we used an inclusive tone of voice
to speak to our audience—makers—about what they
need to do their work: a way to bring their ideas to
life. Then we introduced a way to meet that need:
Makerarm. It’s three sentences long.
Meet Makerarm
As makers, we have ideas all the time—to
improve things, to make our lives better. But to
make our ideas happen, we need access to tons
of machines, materials, and tools that are too
expensive.
That’s why we created Makerarm: a complete
digital fabrication system packed into an
affordable robotic arm that makes just about
anything, anywhere.

HAVE A CLEAR AND CONSISTENT VOICE
When I was first starting out with crowdfunding, I had
a pre-launch ritual I did before each of my campaigns
went live: I’d send the campaign page to my mom.
Why? Because I needed to make sure that someone
totally unfamiliar with the project, product, industry,
and campaign could understand every single thing on
the page. If my mom read something that didn’t make
sense to her, I’d refine the language.
In crowdfunding, you’ve got to communicate
clearly. Being concise and organized on the page goes
a long way. Use bulleted lists and break up your story
with headers. Your campaign page should be easy to
scan, and each section should serve a clear purpose.
The language you use on the page should also be
consistent with language you use everywhere (press,
social media, your website, etc.). That means, of
course, that before launching a campaign, you really
need to know what your core mission is.
Crowdfunders are often still in the early stages of
development, so your messaging may change over
time and that’s ok. But stick to the fundamentals of
who you are and what you do.

IT’S GOT TO BE VISUAL
I find that the way your page looks is one of the most
underestimated aspects of a crowdfunding campaign.
Every project’s story—no matter the category—needs
to be told in a visual way. And those visual assets
(photos, infographics, product images, charts) need to
be professional, on-brand, and meaningful.
If you don’t already have visual brand guidelines, I
recommend that you take time to at least build a
simple style guide for your campaign. Pick the kinds of
colors, photos, and graphics you want to share.
Choose a typeface, too, and keep it consistent. This is
where it can be really valuable to work with a graphic
designer—as you will read about in the next chapter.
As you tell your story on the project page, consider
what will be valuable to show readers. Obviously,
showing your product is the most important thing. For
the Standards Manual reissue, we launched our
Kickstarter campaign before we had any version of the
book from the printer. But we knew backers would
need to visualize the end product in order to buy into
it. So Hamish and Jesse included images of what the
pages would look like once it was printed. (Now on
Kickstarter, projects that involve the making of
physical products need to show working demos of
prototypes. For something like a book, get a sample
made that you can photograph.)
The more complicated your product, the more you

need visuals to make it as clear as possible. With
Makerarm, we had the challenge of demonstrating the
device’s many capabilities in order to appeal to a broad
audience of all kinds of makers. We loaded up the
page with mini videos, images, and animated GIFs. To
give makers an understanding of how Makerarm could
become part of their workspace, we added
illustrations of the device’s specs, including the
weight and dimensions of parts. To show our
audience the tool heads that would come with the
Makerarm, we created illustrated infographics with
line drawings and labels for each one. To clarify what
tools were included with each reward level, we made
an illustrated rewards chart. And to give backers
confidence in our development plan—crucial—we
created a timeline graphic showing exactly when we
planned to build, test, produce, and ship the devices.
For Kickstarter projects where the product will be
manufactured and distributed, you need a working
prototype. (It’s highly encouraged for Indiegogo
hardware campaigns, too.) Use it: take great product
photos of it in use, and show behind-the-scenes
photos of the product in development. Visual video
demos are also a must. Include the essential ones
with the most important features on the page, and
add the rest over time in your updates. Consider
adding GIFs to quickly show your product in action
without readers needing to press “play.” Film projects
can take a similar approach with production
photography as well as photos of the team at work
shooting and editing. But remember, even candid

photos should be high quality. No iPhone pics!
If your rewards are complicated or if they’re
particularly beautiful or ornate (think: a unique
illustrated print from a well-known artist), show them.
If you have a complicated development phase
ahead of you, create a timeline and show potential
backers each step of your process.
You can continue to build a visual story throughout
your campaign. As press comes in, add linked media
logos at the top of the page to show there’s activity
and buzz around your campaign.
Get creative and have fun! People will connect with
the visual components of your page faster than if they
have to read about every aspect of your project.
And if you’re wondering whether all these visual
components are going to make your campaign page
too long, I will add that, personally, I am completely
fine with long pages when they’re mostly made up of
visual material. If you have hi-res, beautiful product
images you want to continue sharing, you can still add
them at the end, after all the necessary information is
already communicated, so that those who want to
keep scrolling can.

INTRODUCE YOURSELF AND YOUR TEAM
In most of our campaigns, we add a section on the
project page to introduce the creator and the whole
team behind the project (that’s in addition to the
creator profile). Backers want to be a part of a story,
and you are part of that story.
Logistically, backers should also know that you are
experienced and the right person to do this project.
Offering information about yourself and about your
team allows them to trust that you are capable of
getting the job done.

LENGTH AND STRUCTURE WILL VARY
Click around any crowdfunding site and you’ll see as
many different structures and stories as there are
projects. The structure of your page will depend on
the needs of your project.
Make sure each section serves a purpose. Include
strong keywords and section titles that grab attention
and revolve around your project’s mission. Use
headers to divide up sections, include visuals
throughout the page, use bold styling, and incorporate
line breaks so no part of the page is too text heavy.
For many campaigns I’ve managed, like the
Standards Manuals campaign, we told a strong story
in short, powerful bursts of text with plenty of images
in between. I reference this campaign all the time
when pointing to examples of projects with great page
lengths and great storytelling. It’s a long page, but it
could have been a very long page if we hadn’t edited it
down (and edited again and again) to distill the story to
the most essential components.
If you’re not sold, here are three more great reasons
to keep your page concise.
You’ll keep your audience’s attention. Campaign
creators feel like so much is riding on their campaign
that they understandably want to communicate every
last detail about their product, mission, and personal

story. However, give your audience the essentials,
and they’ll get it.
You’ll help protect your project from “noodlers.” We
used to jokingly call the people on the Internet who
dissect every phrase in a campaign, scrutinizing a
creator’s knowledge, authenticity, and integrity
“noodlers.” You don’t need to give them so much to
talk about. Stick to your selling points and key
messages—the most important parts of your story—
and you can potentially minimize scrutiny from trolls.
You’ll leave yourself room for growth. Your campaign
should speak to the core mission of your company and
your product because—industry secret!—like almost
everything else you put on the Internet, it may not go
away. After your campaign, your company will likely
expand, pivot, reposition itself, and evolve, especially
within the first couple of years after your campaign.
The closer you stay to who you are, the less criticism
you may draw for having portrayed your business one
way during a campaign only to dramatically change
your product and story later.

BE OPEN ABOUT RISKS AND CHALLENGES
It’s critical to establish trust with potential backers,
and one of the biggest ways to do that is by
addressing risks and challenges on your campaign
page head-on. Use this section to be honest about
what challenges you may face in the fulfillment phase.
If you’re producing a film, there may be delays in
delivering the digital copies, depending on your
distributor’s timeline. If you’re creating a book, there
may be delays in printing. If you’re manufacturing
products on a large scale, there will probably be
unexpected production issues.
The best thing is always to be upfront about risks,
then be solutions-oriented. Think ahead to make real
contingency plans for confronting these challenges,
and then explain them in this section. It’s okay if you
face problems along the way; the most important
thing to communicate is your commitment to being
transparent with backers and your commitment to
finding solutions.

FAQS
On Kickstarter, the FAQ section is something you can
fill out only after you launch. Usually, my team and I
monitor the questions coming in on social media or in
the comments on the page, and when we see trends
in what people are asking about, we add and answer
those questions in the FAQ section for everyone to
see.
But even before that, you should anticipate what
you think backers will have questions about and be
prepared with pre-written FAQs and their answers
before launch, ready to post when you go live.
Chances are, though, if something is an important part
of your campaign—like shipping or technical specs—it
belongs on your project page, and not just in your FAQ
section. The FAQ is at the bottom of the page and can
be missed, so if something is a critical topic, include it
directly on your page. On Indiegogo, there isn’t a
separate FAQ section, but you can add your own or
just make sure to address contributors’ questions in
the content of your page.
As you develop your campaign page, browse other
projects for inspiration. Campaign pages can look
deceptively easy to put together, but they actually
take a ton of time to draft and design. It’s not an easy

task to define you, your project, and your story in
short, easy-to-understand pieces, so start early, get
feedback, and revise it until you feel you’ve got it
nailed.

Chapter 5
Crowdfunding: Marketing for
This Century
Leicester, U.K.–based journalist Eliot Higgins started
blogging about the Syrian conflict in 2012. He’d never
actually been to a war zone, hadn’t studied journalism,
and was no expert on weaponry. But what Eliot lacked
in training and expertise he made up for tenfold in
studied patience, attention, and focus, all channeled
toward YouTube and social media.
At the time, Syrians were uploading videos of
military offenses, civilian casualties, speeches,
propaganda, evidence of war crimes, and all kinds of
weaponry. Eliot, from his home in Leicester, England,
began obsessively devoting himself to studying
everything he could find about the Syrian conflict. It
had been notoriously difficult to report on, but Eliot
didn’t need to be in Syria to break stories—he could
do it all online.
He reported what he learned on his blog, called the
Brown Moses Blog, the name coming from an online
pseudonym taken from a Frank Zappa song. He
figured the only people who would read it were his

friends and maybe his Twitter followers, but within a
year of running the Brown Moses Blog, Eliot was
making astonishing discoveries. He had helped reveal
that particular cluster munitions were being used by
the Syrian government, that Saudis were providing
weapons to the Syrian opposition, and—the big one—
the type of rockets that were used during the
chemical attacks in August 2013 near Damascus.
Eliot, a “one man intelligence agency,” as he later
called himself, had found ways to break news about
weapons that many mainstream news organizations
could not. He was increasingly seen as a leader of a
new kind of journalism. Why? Eliot wanted to know
more about the things he could see coming from
conflict zones on social media, and no one else was
answering his questions.

THE PROJECT: BELLINGCAT.COM
A friend introduced me to Eliot by email. I’d read a
profile on him in the New Yorker and was very excited
about the prospect of working with him, and this
seemed like the perfect opportunity to do something
totally different from my other projects.
Eliot needed to fund his new project: a website
called Bellingcat that would bring together citizen
investigative journalists to use open-source
information in order to investigate, collaborate, and
report on worldwide issues that are being
underreported or ignored (including the Syrian conflict,
and beyond). Eliot also wanted to provide tools to
journalists who had not been traditionally trained, just
like him.
When we got a chance to connect over email,
though, he told me he had great news: a big-name
digital publisher was interested in funding the site, so
he didn’t need to crowdfund anymore. I thought I’d
missed my opportunity to be involved with this
fascinating project. Then I had an idea.

Crowdfunding Offers So Much More Than Just Funding
If successful, a crowdfunding campaign gets you
the money you need to make your project,
product, or business a reality. But crowdfunding
can offer so much more than the opportunity to
get cash. In fact, Evan Cohen, the past senior
director of design, technology, and hardware at
Indiegogo has told me the following:
Crowdfunding provides a ton of organic
press opportunities and a ton of organic
sharing. Consumers are far more excited
and engaged in what you’re trying to do
because they recognize it’s not a pre-order
store. With crowdfunding, after I make a
pledge, the first thing I’m prompted to do
is share—which is a totally different
psychology compared to buying an item
anywhere else. That call-to-action results
in a significantly higher amount of organic
traffic and evangelism for a product. The
concept of crowdfunding itself is driven by
social shares and virality. It means you
have a potential to reach a much bigger
audience.
I couldn’t agree more. In my experience, there

are three key ways crowdfunding benefits
creators beyond just raising money.
Market testing. You get to engage directly with
consumers and see how your idea is received.
Generating publicity. When done well,
crowdfunding campaigns are big events with high
stakes and a lot of excitement. They’re a way to
present your project with a bang.
Expanding your audience. Launching your project
through crowdfunding means you’re likely to get
more attention than if you launched any traditional
way. You really are building a community that will
live on long after the campaign. And because your
backers can communicate with you, it’s also an
opportunity to get insight and feedback on your
project, and learn more about what they want and
who they are.
I told him we could use the crowdfunding campaign
as a marketing tool. What better way to get the word
out about Bellingcat than with a big campaign?
Crowdfunding has become a force to reckon with
when it comes to marketing. Recently, several brands
from all over the world—including big ones like Honda
and GE—have started using crowdfunding as a
marketing resource. At Vann Alexandra, we have
worked with clients that don’t actually need funding
but want to launch on a crowdfunding platform to

make a bigger publicity splash and tap into a huge
community of potential early adopters and fans. With
Bellingcat, I knew we could leverage a campaign for
more than just funding: we could use it for buzz and
audience building, getting more eyes on Eliot’s project
—more journalists, more press, more interest. With
the support of the crowdfunding community, we’d
have a better chance of expanding and energizing
Eliot’s audience. Considering how much this project
deserved attention, it felt like a fit.
Eliot was on board. But he had a scheduled launch
just three weeks later. We had to get to work, and
fast.
Eliot wanted to launch in three weeks because he
planned to have the launch coincide with an
“investigathon” he was attending, hosted by Google
Ideas and the Organized Crime and Corruption
Reporting Project in London. The investigathon was a
seminar about new investigative research tools, set to
be attended by close to 100 journalists. It was a smart
idea. Since the audience would be largely journalists,
Eliot would have an opportunity to talk up his brand-
new project and potentially generate press coverage
as a result. Plus, Eliot said a ton of journalists owed
him a favor. It’d be a perfect way to kick off the
campaign. Now we just had to pull it off in three
weeks.

A Note on In-Person Events on Launch Day
I have had several clients ask about doing Launch
Day events and parties around their campaigns,
and I generally advise against them. Why? You
don’t want people eating, drinking, chatting, and
celebrating when you launch—you want them to
be online! Crowdfunding success happens online,
so that’s where you’ll want your audience to be,
especially when you kick off your campaign and
need momentum. While sometimes people will
write checks at a launch party, the creator then
has to put all that cash into a separate bank
account, which then has to be donated on the
backers’ behalf. Complicated. So my rule of
thumb is no launch events. The only exceptions
might be if your event is going to lead to great
press (as in Eliot’s case) or if there is a major
focus on donating digitally at the party (like a
laptop station that makes it super easy for
backers).

VETTING FOR CROWDFUNDING SUCCESS
Whenever I vet potential projects, I go through an
internal process to figure out, Is this the right fit for
crowdfunding? Each project is different, but I’m
usually looking for a built-in audience and evaluating
whether that audience can convert to dollars.
After going through Eliot’s materials and looking into
his presence online, I knew he had the support
needed to make a successful crowdfunding campaign.
He had a built-in audience. Eliot had a large and
dedicated following through his blog and social media.
They were mostly news junkies who follow the
conflicts in the Middle East, global investigative
reporters, and academics.
His built-in audience was primed to support him.
Eliot’s followers were loyal; they actively engaged
with him online. As the Brown Moses Blog
progressed, Eliot started receiving tips from followers
and experts. People sent him photos and links. When
he came across a weapon he couldn’t identify, he
could post about it and immediately receive input and
ideas from other experts in the field. There was a
collaborative community who rallied together around
this work. Plus, Eliot had previously run a successful

Indiegogo campaign, so clearly his audience was
willing to back him in the past.
He understood the Internet. Eliot was incredibly savvy
when it came to online communication. Because he’d
already been running his blog for a couple years, he
had the advantage of understanding what people were
interested in reading online. He knew how to
communicate in a way that would get people’s
attention and get them excited.
I should also add that this project was pretty much
unlike anything else out there. Eliot was doing
impressive work that could have a huge impact on
people around the world, and I knew his work
deserved the attention a crowdfunding campaign
could provide.
We had the potential for a great campaign. Eliot
came equipped—now we needed to execute.

DIVING IN
After going through all the materials Eliot sent me, I
assessed our immediate needs and priorities. First
priority: the video. We didn’t have one, and we’d need
one in three weeks—less than half the time I’d
normally recommend. Beyond that, we needed to
start drafting a pre-launch email and the project page,
refine Eliot’s rewards ideas, and start planning press
pitches and outreach. Social media was going to play a
big role once we went live, so we had to start thinking
about a communication strategy.
At this point, the Bellingcat website was in beta.
Even though Eliot was expecting funding from another
outlet, he still needed additional cash to finish site
development, make sure it would be up and running
for the first six months, and cover administrative fees.
Eliot wanted to set our fundraising goal at £47,000
($80,000 at that time) to cover those costs.
There was a lot to do, but I felt like it was feasible to
get it all done. My team got to work brainstorming on
the video and drafting the materials. Then I showed
Hamish the Bellingcat logo Eliot sent over. Wait a
minute.

A LOGO REDESIGN THAT QUESTIONED
EVERYTHING
When Hamish saw the logo, he immediately said,
“This isn’t right. It looks like it’s for Napster, not for a
serious website for investigative journalists.”
Even though this project wasn’t geared toward an
audience of designers, Hamish had shown me just
how important good design is when introducing a new
product. (In other words, good design always
matters.) For our campaign to be successful and have
the marketing impact we hoped, we had to make sure
Bellingcat’s branding gave the same impression its
mission did: ambitious and affecting. Hamish and I
agreed the Napster-like logo Eliot had in mind for
Bellingcat wasn’t going to work.
Right away, Hamish offered to redo the Bellingcat
logo—he thought that Eliot’s work supported an
important cause and wanted to help in the best way
he could. I reached out to Eliot and said that Hamish,
who worked at one of the leading design firms in the
world, was also a big fan of his work and wanted to
redo his brand identity, free of charge. Eliot was
onboard and grateful for the offer.
From there, Hamish would come home from his
full-time job and work late nights on rebranding
Bellingcat. He put together a 29-page presentation,
which we went through with Eliot over Skype. The
presentation started with the current logo, showing

how close it was to the Napster logo.
Then it covered the story of the name itself.
“Bellingcat” comes from a fable, called Belling the
Cat, about a group of mice who devise a plan to put a
bell on a threatening cat so they know when it’s
coming. But then an important question arises: Who is
to bell the cat? The mice realize that their grand plan
has a flaw: none of them are willing to go on the risky
mission of slipping the bell around the cat’s neck.
From the story comes the idiom “to bell the cat,”
which means to attempt an extremely risky task.
Bellingcat is about surmounting difficult tasks in part
by asking questions: Investigating, questioning,
digging deeper, finding answers, turning things on
their head, and asking more questions. So Hamish
started his design with a question mark, and then he
turned it on its head.
He replaced the i in Bellingcat with the upside-down
question mark. On its own, the inverted question mark
also resembles the shape of a “b,” and of a bell, so it
was effective as a stand-alone logo, too.

Crowdfunding Design Best Practices
Evaluate your project’s brand identity (logos,
fonts, colors) before your crowdfunding
campaign. Is it effective, established, clear,
cohesive, and professional? Be sure to have
strong visuals on the campaign page, including:
• The main image. Does it grab your
attention?
• The project avatar.
• The title cards on the video. Make them
big enough to read!
• Images and graphics that help tell the
project story and/or clearly and
beautifully show your product. You can
use GIFs or have a designer add text
overlay to images to serve as graphics.
There’s room to get creative!
• Images and graphics of rewards.
• Some projects include an infographic or
a timeline graphic to visually represent
the shipping schedule for rewards.
• Be consistent across platforms, in your
social media, stamped onto your
rewards, etc.
• Beautiful photography is key. Use a
digital SLR if you can, and get a

photographer to help when possible.
It’s true: a picture is worth a thousand
words.
• If you can’t hire a designer and a
photographer, there are plenty of
tutorials online to get you started. But if
your budget allows, the investment in
professionals will pay for itself.
With the new logo, Hamish created design assets
for Eliot: a header and icon for Twitter, a banner and
icon for Facebook, a press release, and all the versions
of hi-res logos he needed (in different colors and
sizes). We were so happy with the final product that
we also used the logo for the rewards, on t-shirts and
in a sticker pack.
Looks do matter when it comes to marketing.
Before Hamish’s redesign, someone might have
looked at the original logo and thought, “That reminds
me of something from the early 2000s…” But now,
with a bold, clean, and clear mark, people might be
intrigued and want to learn more. That in itself is
valuable because it attracts people—reaching beyond
Eliot’s built-in audience to those who might not have
known about Brown Moses in the first place but were
interested in his work. That’s how great design can
help strengthen your marketing impact.

VIP ACCESS: A £5 MARKETING TACTIC
At the time of the campaign, Bellingcat.com was still
in beta. So it wasn’t open to the public, but much of it
was up and running, and it could be accessed by
those who had a code. Already expert journalists and
writers were sharing content and posting on the site,
but the audience was limited to a small group with
access. This provided a unique opportunity for us. We
decided to set the lowest reward level at £5 and
offered exclusive access to the Bellingcat beta site.
(That was about $8.50 at the time. The point was
offering a low-level pledge amount, of course, so a
U.S.-based campaign might use $5.) We wrote this
reward description: “Exclusive Beta Access: Within 24
hours, we will give you exclusive access to the beta
version of bellingcat.com. We will also add your name
to a list of supporters worldwide who helped make
this happen in a special section of the website. We’re
a team and you’re a part of it.”
We wanted to provide an enticingly low barrier to
entry for Eliot’s supporters in hopes we’d get a lot of
backers coming in at that reward level. That way, we’d
get people using and talking about the site. Then if
those with access to Bellingcat tweeted about or
shared Bellingcat content, the only way their friends
and followers could see the site would be to also back
the campaign and get the access code. With enough
social sharing and buzz, we hoped to use this

exclusive access reward as a way to get people
curious—extending our marketing reach and ultimately
driving pledges.

GOING LIVE
Miraculously, we got the campaign ready to go—
including the logo redesign—in three weeks, just in
time for the day of the investigathon.
After we launched, on July 14, 2014, the first few
days of the campaign were steady. We got solid press
as a result of the investigathon, and early pledges
were coming on. Eliot wrote his last post on Brown
Moses explaining the new website and the Kickstarter
project to readers of his blog.
On Days 2 and 3, he posted updates on the
Kickstarter campaign page about the content available
on Bellingcat. The updates served as a teaser for the
content that could only be accessed by pledging £5 to
get on Bellingcat.com. At the end of his posts, Eliot
would write something along the lines of: “Access to
the beta of Bellingcat is available to everyone
contributing £5 or more to the Bellingcat Kickstarter
campaign, so please donate and keep spreading the
word.” We shared the updates on social media,
getting people curious. Pledges continued to come in,
and the plan seemed to be working.
Then, on Day 4, something tragic happened that no
one could have expected, and it directly impacted our
campaign.

MH17 AND WHAT I LEARNED ABOUT KICKSTARTER UPDATES
On July 17, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17)
went down. The passenger flight was carrying 283
passengers and 15 crew, and traveling from
Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur, when it lost contact
near the Ukraine-Russia border and then crashed near
Torez, Ukraine, in a conflict zone. Quickly, stories
began circulating that the plane had been shot down.
Immediately, Eliot got to work. This was exactly the
type of incident he would normally investigate online,
and he started searching for pieces of the puzzle. On
July 17, the same day of the crash, he posted on
Bellingcat about what he’d found. In his post, called
“Geolocating the Missile Launcher Linked to the
Downing of MH17,” Eliot recounted his process step-
by-step, and concluded with how he found the
location of what could allegedly have been the Buk
missile launcher associated with the crash.
It was a remarkable piece of research and a fresh
demonstration of the importance of the work of citizen
journalists like Eliot.
A couple days later, he explained his work in a
public Kickstarter update: “Over the last 48 hours,
using a variety of open source investigation
techniques, it has been possible to identify the precise
location some of these images were taken, confirming
key claims about the location of the Buk missile
launcher.” In the update, Eliot invited readers to back
the project in order to keep reading. We also took the

conversation to social media, where Eliot became one
of the people behind one of 2015’s most influential
hashtags, #MH17. We hoped to encourage
prospective backers to pledge to get access to Eliot’s
amazing work and to help Bellingcat become a reality.
The value of this kind of citizen journalism seemed
more apparent than ever, and we hoped our audience
would see that, too.

How Kickstarter Updates Can Drive Pledges
Eliot’s technique with campaign updates later
made me think more deeply about how to use
updates strategically on Kickstarter.
On Kickstarter, you can make your campaign
updates available to everyone (the general public),
only backers, or only backers within a certain tier
(e.g., only those who pledged $50+).
In order for someone to see a backer-only
update, they have to have backed your campaign.
Leveraging this selectivity, you can choose to
make updates that only backers can see, and try
to make the content appealing to nonbackers to
the extent that they’re willing to pledge to see it.
If there’s an intriguing enough update that
someone really wants access to, they might just
back it.
Before you launch, brainstorm how you could
use this approach. Is there something that makes
your campaign different? Could you create a
special update around that—then close it off to be
viewable by only your backers? When you make
some updates only for backers, it also rewards
your backers for being a part of your community
and supporting your project, and reinforces your
connection with them.

WHEN THE PLATFORM DEEPENS YOUR
MARKETING EFFORTS
After the initial flurry of launching followed by MH17,
at about 10 days into the campaign, we’d raised
around £16,000 ($27,000)—less than half of our goal.
We wondered if pledging was progressing a little too
slowly. Did we lose the initial momentum we’d had?
Then we got a boost from Kickstarter. They included
us in their newsletter and our project was the first one
featured. Under a big picture of the new logo,
Kickstarter wrote, “Bellingcat is about citizens using
open source information to investigate and report on
stories that might otherwise go ignored. They’ve
already published groundbreaking work related to the
recent Flight MH17 tragedy, but there’s way more to
be done.”
We were thrilled, and we saw a bump in pledges
come in almost immediately. Kickstarter is a powerful
marketing engine in itself—a platform with a ton of
eager backers ready to support important projects like
Bellingcat. While getting featured by Kickstarter is
never something you can count on as it’s up to their
curatorial team, I wasn’t shocked that Kickstarter
chose a project like this to promote. “Unique” barely
begins to describe it—Bellingcat was truly a one-of-a-
kind campaign. When a campaign is that special,
Kickstarter notices. It was one of the biggest
marketing boosts we could have gotten.

With less than a week left in our timeline, we
reached our £47,000 goal, and then went on to raise a
total of £50,891 ($87,500) from 1,701 backers.

AFTERMATH
The Bellingcat campaign is one of my proudest
accomplishments. Soon after it wrapped, journalists
on the site allegedly uncovered (or claimed to have
found) the location of an Islamic State (ISIS) training
camp in Iraq using Google Earth, located where
journalist James Foley had been killed, and showed
that the Buk missile launcher linked to the downing of
MH17 in Ukraine was under the control of separatists
and that it originated from Russian troops. Seeing the
website running in full force, with top journalists from
around the world covering some of the biggest and
most important global stories, feels amazing.
The big thing I learned from this campaign?
Crowdfunding truly is a robust marketing tool—
especially when you go the extra mile with your
content (like with fantastic design and exclusive
updates).
Eliot was in a good position to succeed with his
Internet savvy and his engaged audience. But putting
a campaign like this on a crowdfunding platform also
gave us access to an audience that may never have
heard about or seen the Bellingcat site otherwise,
especially once we made it into the Kickstarter
newsletter.
If I had any doubts about the value of great design
in crowdfunding, the Bellingcat campaign wiped them
away. I’m confident our redesign made an impact.

Now, I always emphasize to clients that to have an
effective marketing campaign with crowdfunding, you
need to optimize your visual brand. A huge part of
building an image that’s perceived as professional,
well-produced, and trustworthy is having design
elements that are equally professional and well
produced. As Hamish said in an article for CNBC on
design in crowdfunding, “Amateur hour is over.”

Chapter 6
Budgeting, Rewards, and Tips
from the Trenches
As of 2016, Kickstarter campaign success rates hover
around 36 percent. That means that the rest—about
two-thirds of all campaigns—fail.
The truth is, crowdfunding is really, really hard. Over
the course of my career, I’ve had anxiety attacks,
breakdowns, and painful conversations with clients.
I’ve faced big challenges, and I’ve made mistakes. But
experience is a great teacher, and the end result is
that my team and I have learned a lot in the
crowdfunding trenches.
While no campaign will ever be bulletproof, so many
mistakes are avoidable. Common crowdfunding
pitfalls involve budgeting, rewards, and fulfillment. But
there are ways to avoid mishaps from the get-go, like
by having a well-thought-out budget and
implementation strategy in place for delivering on your
promises. In this chapter, I’ll guide you through how to
budget, how to plan and execute on great rewards,
and how to avoid other crowdfunding missteps.

HAVE A BUDGET
Not being able to deliver your product or rewards, or
losing money doing it, is a nightmare scenario no
creator ever wants to find him/herself in. So you have
to be hypervigilant about budgeting.
It’s crucial to account for every line item required to
prepare, execute, and complete your campaign,
especially the post-campaign costs of rewards
fulfillment. When you begin planning your
crowdfunding campaign, make a budget spreadsheet
early on and continue to update it as you plan (you will
find a sample sheet in the Resources section at the
end of this book). Don’t skimp on the research phase
here. When you sit down to assess your expenses,
here are some production costs to include in your
estimated budget.
Production of your product. Make sure you have a
good understanding of each step required to make
your project a reality. Most creators think they have a
good sense of what this number will be, but it’s worth
taking a second and third look. If you’re raising money
for post-production of your documentary, for example,
make sure you’ve estimated what it will cost to do all
editing, color correction, design, and every other cost
to finalize your film. Also, make sure you know who
you’ll need to hire and how much you’ll pay each team

member. If you’re raising money for a product, make
sure that you’ve built prototypes and understand the
costs required for making every component.
Production of your campaign. Consider costs like
hiring a designer, a videographer, and/or a consultant
like yours truly to launch the campaign. Consider costs
for getting legal and accounting advice. If you don’t
already have a website, that’s an additional cost. If you
plan to advertise on social media, that’s another cost.
Consider everything that you’ll spend to get your
campaign up and running.
Production of each reward (if different from your
product). Know exactly how much it will cost to
produce and deliver on each reward. Be precise. It’s
not good enough to have an estimate.
Shipping costs for rewards. If you’re doing your own
shipping, know the costs of postage, envelopes,
shipping labels, the printer and toner costs of printing
those labels, and how much in booze you’ll need for
“paying” your friends who are stuffing those
envelopes. If you’re going to work with a logistics
company, make sure they quote you up front for the
cost of receiving your product, storing your product,
then shipping your product. Get their rates for boxes
and understand what happens if there is a problem.

For instance, what if every box must be opened and
something must be changed? You’ll probably also
need a conservative estimate of how long you might
keep products in the warehouse, so that you can
factor this into your overall costs, and the future sale
price. Be super careful with shipping calculations—
you’ll need to get meticulous. For example, some
carriers ship by weight and by carton size, and while
you might find that it’s $10 to ship a 2-pound package,
it could be $100 to ship a 2-pound package that’s 50
inches long. There’s plenty of information available
online about shipping costs, so read up.
Add in the variable costs and fees of the crowdfunding
platform. Kickstarter and Indiegogo both collect a
small (but significant) percentage of the total funds
you raise, in addition to processing and transaction
fees. Check the rules and details on each site. If
you’ve hired a consultant whose commission will be
based on the percent you earn, include that variable
cost as well.
Calculate a 15 percent buffer. Extra production costs
and unexpected expenses invariably come up. You
might find yourself mid-campaign needing more
momentum, so you decide to invest in digital
marketing. (Or, yikes, you missed a cost in your
budget somewhere.) Something like this is bound to
happen, so add a buffer. Generally, we say around 15

percent, but figure out what works for you. If you do
manage to avoid needing the extra money raised, you
have plenty of options to use that profit in other ways:
• You can pay back yourself and your team for
the time put into the campaign.
• You can pay your designer, videographer, or
another campaign collaborator a bonus,
especially if they gave you a great discount.
• You can enhance your product. Get better
paper for your book. Hire another editor to
speed up delivery of your film.
• You can put the money toward your product,
brand, and business. Your campaign was
just the beginning—now it’s time to run a
business!
Add the buffer to the other costs, and you’ll arrive at
your goal. It’s important to calculate this exactly
because you want to launch with the lowest possible
number, so that you can try to get to that number as
soon as you can. Of course, this cost breakdown list is
not the same for every project. To get the exact
information you need for your budget, be sure to talk
to an accountant, fulfillment partner, production
partner, and others! You want to get these costs
nailed down.

GET A PARTNER
I recommend that my clients use a production partner
who can both produce rewards (t-shirts, stickers,
postcards, posters, etc.) and ship them, when
possible. However, this probably won’t apply to most
product-based campaigns. For those, some fulfillment
houses can be connected to the production house and
coordinate. Either way, get help. Believe me,
fulfillment is rough. You won’t want to make and then
individually ship every reward yourself if you can avoid
it.
Finding a partner or partners will take research.
Kickstarter and Indiegogo both have resources on their
site with information about potential partners and
services, including companies that specialize in
manufacturing, fulfillment, packaging, and shipping.
Get quotes and talk with a few partners before your
campaign launch. In my experience, production and
shipping facilities generally need to know a minimum
number of each item you anticipate needing to
produce and ship—that’s what they base the
production quote on.
Once you’ve decided on a company to partner with,
review prices for domestic and international shipping.
The distributor can tell you the cost of shipping each
of your rewards—depending on size, weight, and
packaging—around the world. Then backers will be
able to pay for shipping at checkout (on platforms like

Kickstarter and Indiegogo). But before launch, you
need to enter the shipping amounts from the
distributor into the platform (or it could be embedded
in the pledge amount). Part of your buffer should
include padding these amounts, too.

That Time We Shipped Rewards Ourselves
And swore we’d never do it again
Earlier in my career, I signed on to do fulfillment
for a film campaign. Nowadays, we make it so
that fulfillment is handled by our clients, but in
this case, I agreed to handle it. Why? The clients
were well-established filmmakers, and I was
pretty star struck.
In short: fulfillment was very tough.
We encountered issues at every step. By this
time, I had assembled a small team to work
alongside me in my crowdfunding business, and
my new coworkers and I were moving into our
very own office space. Exciting! But very quickly,
our office became crowded with rewards. We
had stuff—DVDs, tote bags, posters, postcards,
boxes, envelopes, and shipping materials—on our
desks, under our desks, everywhere. The
holidays were approaching, and we had to get
everything shipped quickly. It took one of my
hard-working project managers an entire week to
package and label rewards.
We planned to print shipping labels in the
office, but because of technical issues with the
online postage site, we ended up taking over a
hundred packages to the post office in giant Ikea
bags. The first one we went to was closed due to
a computer problem. From there, we tried a

nearby courier delivery service, but the shipping
options were way too expensive. When we finally
arrived at another post office, it was swarmed
with customers sending out packages before the
holidays. The unlucky attendant who ended up
assisting us scanned each of our 150 packages,
one by one. It took about an hour and a half.
Understandably, the people behind us in line
were not pleased. A very polite older woman
introduced herself as a concerned member of the
community and asked how we could ensure that
something like this wouldn’t happen again.
Needless to say, by the end of the shipping
adventure, it was painfully clear that this was not
the way to do it. The time commitment was too
great, the process was inefficient, and it wasn’t
an effective way to run a business. (Imagine if we
had had to ship 1,500 rewards, not 150!) And this
