• Add a hashtag you’ve been using for
the campaign, along with industry-
specific ones.
• Mention timing to create urgency.
• Translate: if your audience includes an
international demographic, share posts
in different languages.
• Talk to your audience—ask a question,
open a discussion, ask for feedback, or
ask them to share your post if they
agree/like what they see.
• Include the campaign link—so
important! (Try using a customized
bit.ly link for a cleaner look.)

LET’S DO THIS
When your campaign goes live, you’ll have it all lined
up: press that will go live, influencers that will show
their support, great content you’ll share on social
media, and emails to send. But Launch Day is just the
first day in a 30-something-day sprint. You get to see
your planning come to life, and from there you need to
continually be evaluating what’s working and what’s
not.
At minimum, you should prepare to spend an hour a
day on social media, but on many days it will be more
than that—you’ll want to monitor what’s going on at
different times of day. The goal is to populate the
page and stay active. As you post at different times of
day, you can start to understand what times work
better with your audience (be cognizant of time
zones).
During the campaign, it’s all about looking at the
data and seeing what it tells you.
• Look at user similarities. We see what
people talking about the campaign have in
common. You might see that, say, all people
posting are creatives in a certain field, most
of whom live in San Francisco and are men
in their 40s. You can use that information to
tailor your content as well as your press

approach—maybe you’ll decide to target
regional press in San Francisco.
• Log in to each social platform and search
hashtags, the product name, and the
campaign link to see what people are saying
and sharing.
• Research—surprise!—influencers. You may
get influencers sharing your campaign
organically. When we find people with large
followings sharing and talking about our
campaign, we Google them to learn more.
There might be a press angle there, like
when we saw that Katy Perry had backed
the TLC campaign.
• Search keywords. You can search Twitter,
Instagram, and Facebook for keywords at
different times of day to see when
conversations are happening. With
Hootsuite, you can have an automated
search running around the clock, tracking
when certain notable posts go up, so you
know when your own posts might get the
most engagement.
• Look for red flags. Try to see if people are
posting anything negative about the product
or campaign and try to understand why,
based on what people are saying and
sharing. Then build a narrative around how
you can answer and address the issue or

question people have.
• See what’s converting. On the dashboard,
we see if social media is generating
conversions and, if so, we determine how to
keep it going. Follow what’s working!
Crowdfunding is risky. One of the big reasons my
team and I feel confident enough to launch campaign
after campaign is that we know it pays to create
strong press strategies, influencer partnerships, and
social media campaigns. This preparation is really
valuable. No matter how great your idea, product, or
project is, it won’t matter if you’re not connected to an
audience. All creators need to be prepared to roll up
their sleeves and use these tools to their advantage. It
works—and it’s fun!

Chapter 8
Exclusive Access and What
Joan Didion Taught Me
On November 21, 2014, shortly before Thanksgiving
and exactly 30 days after it launched, the Joan Didion
documentary Kickstarter campaign ended. It had
raised $221,135, nearly tripling the original goal.
Within hours of launching, the campaign had blown
up, and then, roughly 24 hours after going live, it
already hit its funding goal. The Guardian, the New
York Times, the LA Times, NPR, Vogue, NYMag.com,
Time, Jezebel, and many other media outlets covered
it, and the campaign was shared thousands upon
thousands of times on social media. There was a
lineup of newly interested investors and even offers of
a book deal with the director. It was complete Didion
mania.
The campaign to kickstart the “Didion Doc” taught
me a lot about this business. Even though Joan
Didion’s fame made this campaign a special one,
much of what I learned I now apply to all Kickstarter
projects, and they can be incorporated into your
campaign, too.

A FAMILY AFFAIR
On a hot September day in 2014, I met film producer
Annabelle Dunne for coffee in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
We sat down to discuss the documentary she wanted
to crowdfund about the famous American writer Joan
Didion. Annabelle is a film producer by trade, and she
also happens to be Joan Didion’s niece.
Joan Didion, who was born in 1934 in Sacramento,
California, worked as a copywriter and associate editor
at Vogue in New York as a young woman. After
meeting her husband, the writer John Gregory Dunne,
the two moved to California, where she continued her
writing career. She published her first collection of
nonfiction essays, Slouching Towards Bethlehem, in
1968, and, over the following decades, continued to
publish books, essays, articles, and screenplays for
film and the stage (The Panic in Needle Park, Up Close
& Personal), many along with her husband, who was
her creative partner. After the unexpected death of
both her husband and daughter, in short succession,
she published The Year of Magical Thinking (2005) and
Blue Nights (2011), reflecting on these tragedies. In
2005, Didion won the National Book Award for
nonfiction for The Year of Magical Thinking, and later
received the National Book Foundation’s prestigious
Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American
Letters. She was awarded honorary degrees at
Harvard and Yale. In 2013, the White House named

her a recipient of a National Humanities Medal,
presented by President Obama.
I had read some of Joan Didion’s essays and loved
them, and I was familiar with her status as a literary
icon. A recent story in the Atlantic described her
perfectly as “revered (worshipped, in many cases) as
much for her glamorously aloof public persona as for
her infectious, revolutionary-in-its-time prose style” in
young literary and fashion circles. I’d witnessed this
myself in my early 20s as a journalist in New York; it
seemed like most of my friends and colleagues were
obsessed with her work.
Annabelle and I hit it off right away. She explained
that she was producing the film with her cousin,
director Griffin Dunne, Joan Didion’s nephew, and
with producer Mary Recine. A couple years prior, they
had shot a short video for her Blue Nights book tour.
They realized that the short film was just the tip of the
iceberg and set out to make a feature-length
documentary. “After hours of watching [Joan Didion]
read and reflect it became clear that we could not stop
there—we had to do something much larger and
deeper,” the creators later explained on the campaign
page. “Storytelling was a way of enduring the potent
rawness Joan experienced through life, and through
loss. Now we must be the ones to preserve this. To
preserve her legacy.” The documentary had a working
title of We Tell Ourselves Stories in Order to Live,
named after a collection of Didion’s writing and a
tribute to her essence as writer and human being.
The filmmakers had shot many hours of footage

with their own funding, and the next step was to
continue production by interviewing Joan Didion’s
friends, colleagues, and others influenced by her,
including Patti Smith, Vanessa Redgrave, Michelle
Williams, Annie Leibovitz, Anna Wintour, and Graydon
Carter, among others. The issue, however, was that
no one was interested in investing in the film. Griffin
later told Variety.com, “It was not an easy sell.…
People were respectful and said they were fans of
Joan, but they didn’t see much of an audience.”
The filmmakers had considered crowdfunding, but
they knew they didn’t have a team in place to run a
campaign well. When a friend mentioned my success
in crowdfunding to Annabelle, she thought, Why not?

AN AMBITIOUS PROJECT WITH HIGH STAKES
Around the time I met Annabelle, Vann Alexandra had
grown to a team of three (soon to be four), and we
were taking on bigger and bigger projects. We’d
completed the Neil Young campaign that spring and
collaborated on a couple technology projects over the
summer, and we were running the epic NYCTA
manual campaign, all of which put more experience
under our belts when it came to large-scale
campaigns.
At this point, I’d successfully crowdfunded several
documentaries, but this felt like it could be our biggest
one yet. Still, I was starting to form a strong belief that
for documentaries to get crowdfunded, they needed
to have a socially focused cause behind them. Joan
Didion was an important figure and an incredible
author, but I wondered, Would people want to put
money toward a documentary about a writer?
Despite not knowing the answer, I felt there was
enough going for this project for it to be successful,
and signed on. I believed in what the team was doing.
I believed in Joan Didion. And I believed we could
figure out the rest.

BUILDING A CAMPAIGN AROUND EXCLUSIVE
ACCESS
With the project a go, I sat down with my team to get
to work. When we took a step back and asked what
was at the heart of this campaign, it was immediately
clear the answer was Joan Didion herself. But
although she has always been open in her writing—
about her love life, her struggles, and her family—she
has also been a notoriously private person when it
comes to press and appearances. And, at 79 years
old, she wasn’t making many public appearances and
did very little, if any, press. But her fans wanted to get
close to her. Even though she wouldn’t be directly
involved in the campaign (something Annabelle made
clear from the beginning), the film was being made
with Joan Didion’s approval and by her own family,
who knew her best and could tell her story from a
personal perspective. As it later said at the beginning
of the campaign page, “Incredibly, this story has never
been told. Now that we have the access, we must tell
it. This is our chance to be Joan’s witness.”
What I liked about the dynamic was it was so clear
that Annabelle and Griffin highly respected and loved
their aunt very much, and were very protective of her.
We believed that for this campaign to raise the level
of community involvement we were looking for, we
had to allow backers to get up close and personal with
Joan Didion through the campaign in a way that had

never been possible before. We realized that was
really the best way to get her fans involved in making
this documentary happen.
We decided we’d use the Kickstarter video and a
robust social media campaign to show fans never-
before-seen footage of Joan Didion and get them
excited about the documentary. We’d also create
unique rewards that only people with access to Joan
Didion could offer, in the hope that they’d be
irresistible. Here’s how we did it.

A CLOSE-UP VIDEO PORTRAYAL
In the coworking space in Greenpoint where my
colleagues and I worked, we sublet a few desks from
Rafael and Ava of RAVA Films. I’d been wanting to
work with them for awhile and the Didion Doc
seemed like the right opportunity, so I pitched them
the idea, and they were in.
We planned for Griffin to be the voice of the
campaign video so he could talk candidly about his
aunt Joan and why he and his cousin, Annabelle, felt
compelled to make the documentary. With Griffin
telling the story, viewers could get access to Joan
Didion in a new way, through someone who had
grown up with her in the family.
Rafael and Ava decided to set up the interview with
Griffin at his home. As documentary filmmakers
themselves, they were skilled at making interview
subjects feel comfortable, even when surrounded by
video and audio equipment. They eased into the
interview with Griffin, and then got into some really
personal and challenging questions. Griffin spoke
about what was so special about his aunt, reflecting
on her life as both a prolific writer and as the aunt who
he continues to admire and love to this day.
RAVA seamlessly combined the interview footage
of Griffin with archival, iconic images of Joan Didion
and included an excerpt from the documentary in
progress. By providing an intimate portrayal of Joan
Didion through the lens of someone who is so close

to her, viewers saw her in a new, highly personal light.
And it was very emotional. People told me they cried
after watching it, which didn’t surprise me, since I had
teared up too.
On Launch Day, the Guardian wrote about the
video: “One particularly poignant scene features
Didion at her desk, reading from her computer screen:
‘Life changes fast. Life changes in the instant.’ It’s the
opening words to Didion’s autobiographical novel The
Year of Magical Thinking.… It’s a moving moment
from the film’s 6-minute trailer and it bodes well for
the power of a full-length documentary.”
Here’s what made the video work.
• It told a story. RAVA made a campaign video
that felt like a story, not a fundraising video.
It was like a trailer for the documentary,
while still managing to cover necessary
ingredients for the Kickstarter campaign
(what the project was about, why we
needed Kickstarter). Because the video was
cinematic, telling a narrative story, it didn’t
feel too long, even though it clocked in at
almost 6 minutes. It wasn’t repetitive, and it
didn’t feel like marketing. (I talk a lot about
making a great video in chapter 2.)
• It provided access. Before launching the
campaign, the public hadn’t seen the
filmmakers’ footage of Joan Didion, like the
scene where she’s sitting at her desk

reading from The Year of Magical Thinking.
The campaign video had to show the access
they had, not only through Griffin’s
memories of his aunt, but also through the
new film footage they had of her. That’s
what was going to make this documentary
so great, and it’s also what made the video
work.
• It was emotional. At the heart of every story
there should be an emotional core that has
the potential to resonate with people. If you
can tap into that, you can harness a real
power—and get people to share your video.
You don’t need celebrity or fame for this.
You just need to know your story and your
audience, and to draw an emotional
connection between them. With Joan
Didion, we underscored themes of
American culture, family, the fragility of life,
grief, and memory. There was the
emotionality from Didion’s story, but beyond
that, there was a sense of emotion from the
director Griffin in his storytelling.

INTIMATE REWARDS
To figure out rewards, we asked ourselves, What
would fans love to get from Joan Didion? In other
words, how could we leverage our access to her to
offer something unique? An autographed book was
obvious. What was something outside the box? After
a lot of researching and reading, my head of projects
at the time proposed a book of Joan Didion’s favorite
recipes—she had been well known for the dinner
parties she and her husband hosted in California in the
’70s. Annabelle found her handwritten personal
recipes, and we scanned them. Hamish was brought
on to design the digital reward assets, and he put the
recipes together in a cohesive, beautifully designed
PDF. Backers were thrilled to get their hands on
something so personal to Didion, and it became one
of the biggest hits among our rewards.
We applied a similar approach to compile a list of
other personal rewards: a handwritten list of Joan
Didion’s twelve most important books to read before
you die; a collection of Saturday Evening Post columns
that she and her husband, John, had written; a
chronicle of Joan Didion’s life and work compiled via
oral history by Annabelle; the opportunity to send a
letter to Didion that would be read to her; and a big
one: a pair of Joan Didion’s iconic sunglasses, donated
by the writer herself.
We also included some typical rewards, like digital
access to the film upon release. Whatever we came

up with, we made sure it connected directly to Joan
Didion. The rewards were all about her, and fans
wanted them. The New York Times called our rewards
“doozies.”

ACCESS THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA
Weeks before launch, we created a Twitter handle
and Instagram account under the name @didiondoc
and started building the social media campaign from
scratch. (Although Joan Didion’s publisher had a
Facebook page with 47,000+ followers and was
supportive of our documentary, the documentary did
not have any social media presence of its own.)
We strategically followed a handful of Twitter and
Instagram accounts run by people who seemed to be
the biggest Joan Didion fans. First and foremost, we
wanted to start conversations with people who could
become our most supportive influencers and create
long-term partnerships with them.
On both Twitter and Instagram, we posted images
that paired beautiful, rare archival photos with quotes
from Joan Didion, initially with no mention of
Kickstarter. (Later, we also shared never-before-seen
stills from the documentary footage.) The visual
medium of Instagram really lent itself to the content,
and it quickly gained more traction than Twitter. The
aesthetic was also intentional: before sharing
anything, we created a style guide where we laid out
exactly the kinds of photos and quotes we wanted to
share. Then Hamish designed simple images
comprised of gorgeous Joan Didion photos with text
overlays.
To get the attention of the Instagram users we
wanted to connect with, we started searching for

great Didion-related photos on Instagram. Images
tagged #joandidion were a great starting point—there
were thousands of them. When we found a good one,
we’d leave a thoughtful comment. We’d also repost
some we really liked on our account, giving the
original user credit by tagging them. As we followed
more accounts and started talking to more users in
the comments, it became clear that some of these
people were big Joan Didion fans who actively posted
about her, followed other users who posted about her,
and who engaged in lots of Joan Didion conversations
on Instagram. If we found a great photo on one
account, sometimes we’d tag a few of the other users
who we knew loved her, as if to say, “Hey, check this
out!” Soon, it started to feel like we were all in a
secret club together.
The great thing about this approach is that it can be
used for any topic, not just for a famous writer like
Joan Didion. Creators can explore Instagram by
searching for keywords related to a campaign in the
search box (for example, we could search
#slouchingtowardsbethlehem, #didion, and more). The
landscape can be overwhelming at first, but the more
you click around and explore, the easier it gets. Follow
your gut on which photos and captions resonate with
you.
Once we hit about 250 organic followers on
@didiondoc, we researched a couple dozen top people
who seemed to be the most engaged. We looked
them up online, checked out their websites, got their
email addresses, and contacted them. In the emails,

we introduced ourselves and asked for their support in
sharing our posts. Sometimes, we also did a bit of
market research: We asked them “What got you
interested in the @didiondoc account? What do you
like most about it?” We used their feedback to tailor
our posts.
The pitching process for influencers went
something like this.
• We emailed the prospective influencer and
explained how we were working on one of
our biggest projects yet: the first and only
documentary about Joan Didion.
• We included the creators behind the project
and shared their accolades (for example,
Griffin, the director, has been nominated for
an Oscar). Name-dropping may be annoying
at a party, but it’s key in cold-pitching your
project!
• We mentioned other amazing interviews we
had already lined up with Joan Didion’s
friends, colleagues, and admirers. This also
gets people’s attention and makes them
feel like they can be a part of something big.
• We then went into our pitch:
To drum up support prior to the campaign
launch we have created Twitter and
Instagram accounts that share images of

Joan, quotes, essays, book reviews, etc.
Both accounts fall under the handle
@didiondoc. We noticed that you are a
fan of Didion’s, and we wanted to make
sure you were aware of this campaign.
We would love this project to take the
Internet by storm the day we launch and
are wondering (and hoping!) if you could
post it on social media when we do (we
will let you know when we launch!).
If you’re interested, we would also love
it if you could even write a piece about
Joan Didion’s influence on your writing,
fashion sense, etc. We want to let the
Didion devotees out there know this film
is happening, and with your support we
know that this campaign will reach our
core audience.
• We finished the pitch by saying “The
campaign is bound to be a hit—Vogue,
Vanity Fair, Elle magazine and a series of
literary magazines are planning on sharing
the campaign.” This showed that we were
serious, and there were serious supporters
behind it.
Meanwhile, the Instagram account kept gaining
followers and became more reputable. People started
tagging us in their photos, hoping we’d choose their

post to repost on our account. Our @didiondoc
account was recognized as special because we had
rare and unseen photos of Joan Didion—we had
access—so we were perceived as reputable, with a
different set of credentials from other typical fan
accounts.
We continued to monitor the social accounts
leading up to Launch Day, checking each day to see
who had followed us. When we noticed renowned
stylist and fashion editor Christopher Niquet was
following the account, we were really excited. With
some clicking around, we found out Christopher
makes charming Joan Didion shirts for his friends just
for fun, and we had an idea: What if we invited him to
offer his shirts as a reward for the campaign? We sent
an email and gave it a shot. Not only was Christopher
totally open to working with us, but he was thrilled to
help. We made a plan for Christopher’s gorgeous Joan
Didion t-shirt to be a special limited offer reward.
It was a revelation to recognize how influencers and
rewards could collide. Our laser-focused and attentive
market research was leading us to discover new
avenues for our campaign, and it was paying off as we
connected with more people who were willing to
support and participate in our project.

GOING LIVE
When it came time to go live, I felt really good about
all our prep work. The video was incredible. The
rewards were very strong. Our Instagram account had
the eyes of supportive followers on it.
Then came Launch Day.
Immediately, pledges started coming in, the
promised press materialized, the momentum on social
media was insane, and our inbox was flooded with
emails. It felt like everyone was talking about the Joan
Didion Kickstarter. The next day, we hit our goal. We
were bowled over. Below are clips from a backer
update we wrote:
Dear Kickstarter backers,
Our entire team at We Tell Ourselves Stories in
Order to Live is absolutely ecstatic that we
reached our goal today. Although we couldn’t be
happier to have received this funding, what we
are truly stunned by is the overwhelming amount
of support we have received from Joan’s devoted
fans—in the form of tweets, comments,
messages, emails, phone calls, resumes…
And now we feel the love for Joan everywhere.
Everyone wants to be involved.
And that is what our goal is: to involve each and
every one of you in this process. We want to

make everyone who has ever loved Joan and her
work feel like they have the opportunity to
connect with her in some small but incredibly
meaningful way.
(She is thrilled by the way about this campaign.
She, like all of us, is constantly refreshing the
Kickstarter page.)
We closed our thank-you note with the
announcement that Christopher Niquet’s shirts were
now available, as he had just submitted his final
design to us. He also gave us the fantastic news that
he was generously donating the shirts to our
campaign. They sold out in a flash.

It’s Okay to Delay Your Launch Day
The day before we were set to launch the Didion
Doc campaign, the world found out that
renowned fashion designer Oscar de la Renta had
died. Much of our audience in the fashion
community and beyond spent the day reading
about and remembering what an influential figure
de la Renta had been. To respect the sentiments
of the fashion community and to give some space
between de la Renta’s passing and our campaign,
we decided to delay launching the Didion
campaign a day. It would have been insensitive
for us to launch (with our press stories, social
media campaigns, and emails) on a day when
much of our audience was paying tribute to a
legendary figure in the industry.
You might be hesitant to delay a launch date
after previously communicating it to an audience;
I say it’s okay to wait. The primary purpose of pre-
launch emails is to serve as a reminder that your
campaign is happening, but people probably
won’t be too nit-picky about the date and time.
The important email is the one you send on
Launch Day with a link to the campaign. If you do
delay or change your campaign launch, the
necessary thing is to let journalists know it’s
being moved, particularly if they have embargoed
stories that are set to go.

OKAY, WE’RE FUNDED: NOW WHAT?
Two days in and we hit our goal. Project’s over. It’s a
wrap. Story ends. Right? Wrong! We were geared up
and ready to work on this project for 28 more days,
and that’s just what we did.
If you ever find yourself in the incredible position of
being fully funded before your deadline, first,
congratulations! But don’t you dare stop there. More
money always helps. It can make the difference
between a so-so film and an amazing, award-winning
final feature that’s perfectly crafted. There’s usually a
reason to keep funding—but you have to get your
audience to believe that, too.
For the Didion Doc project, we made it our goal to
give people a reason to come back to the campaign
page again and again. We went from 100 percent
funded to 276 percent funded. Here’s what we did.

Stretch Goals
Stretch goals are unofficial targets beyond a
project’s funding goal that can be used to entice
new backers to pledge or to encourage current
backers to raise their pledge amount.
Meeting a stretch goal might lead to new and
different rewards for backers, or a more
developed and dynamic product, or it could
accelerate your production timeline. A stretch
goal can be particularly effective when meeting
the goal benefits the entire community of
backers. For instance, if you’re Kickstarting a
video game, more funding might allow you to add
more levels to the game that everyone will get to
enjoy. So even after a goal is met, backers
continue to rally around the campaign and
continue to fund it so they all benefit.
But you have to be careful—stretch goals can
be tricky. If not managed correctly, they can put
you over budget or behind schedule, and possibly
risk muddying the project’s vision. My personal
philosophy is, if you’re going to use stretch goals,
don’t post them on your page from the outset of
your campaign. It looks presumptuous. Instead,
add a budget section to your campaign narrative
and be clear about what you’ll accomplish if you
hit your goal. Explain that your goal will get you to
a certain point, but that you might have more to

accomplish beyond that. You can let backers
know that if you hit your goal, they can expect to
see exciting new rewards or features as part of
your stretch goals.
Stretch goals can be a great tool, but be
mindful of how many you add. With each stretch
goal comes an update to backers, and if you keep
sending those, it can start to feel spammy and
get tuned out. Plus, you need to keep fulfillment
in mind. Always be sure you can deliver on what
you’re promising. If you overfund, focus on giving
people things they actually want without
overdoing it and becoming a sales rep.
• We offered new rewards.
• We posted updates with special content
from guest contributors.
• We kept talking on social media. And we
kept reaching out to new influencers.
• We hosted influencer takeovers of our
Instagram account.
• We cast our net wider with press, targeting
international outlets.
After reaching our goal, our strategy focused almost
entirely on community building through influencers. It
was important to everyone that this campaign didn’t
feel all about the money. The campaign was about
Joan Didion, and about connecting people who loved

her and her work. We weren’t just funding a film, we
were directly engaging with its future audience.

REWARDS
After our great experience with Christopher Niquet’s t-
shirts, we searched for more opportunities to involve
Joan Didion fans. When we saw the awesome New
York illustrator Joana Avillez following us on social
media, we knew we had to reach out. Just like
Christopher, she was happy and honored to be
involved and designed an amazing shirt. About a week
into the campaign, we posted an update announcing
the new reward and it, too, flew off the shelves.
Later in the campaign, we were also able to offer a
print from artist Avery Nejam and a tote from the
Pacific Tote Company, created by Roman Coppola and
the Directors Bureau.
For all influencer rewards, we limited the number
we were offering. It got people following the
campaign closely to see what we’d offer next and to
be ready to pledge quickly if we offered something
appealing.

SPECIAL UPDATES
Another way we nurtured our community and
continued to grow our audience was by keeping fresh
content on the campaign page with guest updates
from influencers. We invited writers to send us a few
hundred words about Joan Didion’s impact on their
lives. We ended up with two beautiful essays, which
we shared on Kickstarter as guest updates. We also
invited everyone to share their stories with the
hashtag #WhatJoanTaughtMe.

TAKEOVERS
During the campaign, in an effort to keep our
Instagram posts relevant and exciting, and to continue
expanding our audience, we invited influencers to
“take over” the account on weekends. Influencers
logged into our @didiondoc Instagram and posted
there for a few days. We also asked that posts be
reshared on personal accounts to encourage
influencers’ audiences to come over to our Instagram.
By the end of the campaign, our Instagram had
expanded from 250 pre-launch followers to having
some 5,000 followers. As of this writing, there are
over 15,000 followers! And the film team keeps it
active. They now have a huge base of supporters
anxiously awaiting the release of the film.

LIFE AFTER KICKSTARTER
Our campaign came to a close on November 21, 2014,
but it seemed like people weren’t ready to stop talking
about Joan Didion. It was like a new conversation had
been stirred up, and the buzz continued on in literary,
fashion, and design circles. All of a sudden, Joan
Didion was having “a moment.” Less than two
months after the campaign ended, it was announced
that she was chosen to be the face of the iconic
French luxury goods brand, Céline. Later, in a New
York Times profile titled “Fashion’s Gaze Turned to
Joan Didion in 2015,” Matthew Schneier wrote about
Didion’s prevalence following the Kickstarter.
Going into a campaign, there’s never a way to know
exactly how it will pan out. The best you can do is
research, prepare, and prepare some more. No one on
our team could have predicted what happened with
the Didion Doc. Griffin later told Variety.com: “We
were flabbergasted by the love and dollars and cents
that came flooding in from all over the world. It was
almost as if people wanted to thank Joan for
everything she’s written. These are passionate fans
who couldn’t wait for this to happen.”
Passionate fans indeed. For me, the campaign’s
explosive quality re-emphasized a lesson I’d learned
many times in crowdfunding: it all comes back to the
importance of having a passionate and engaged
audience.

And not only having that audience, but knowing
them. While it was clear Joan Didion had a strong
following, there wasn’t a market test to see the
numbers and gauge enthusiasm. After we launched, it
became obvious the campaign’s backers were an
Internet-savvy group who were highly engaged and
devoted to the subject matter, just like our niche
audience of passionate designers had been with the
NYCTA manual campaign. With the NYCTA manual,
though, we had seen the standardsmanual.com site
go viral, giving us confidence ahead of time that we’d
have backers for our project. With the Didion Doc, we
didn’t have any stats. I looked back at the campaign
and thought about what worked and what more we
could have done. It boiled down to two big things I
always recommend that any creator do before
launching.
• Create relationships with influencers and
through social media. One thing that really
worked was investing a lot of time up front
with our social media audience building and
influencer research. Emails with influencers
also helped us learn about their preferences.
All creators should do this, and the earlier
you can start, the better. You don’t need to
have a big name or celebrity associated with
your project for people to be interested in it.
Your niche audience is out there; it’s just a
matter of investing the time to research and

connect with them early on.
• Learn about your audience through mini
market research assessments. The Didion
campaign sparked an idea: What if we send
an entire campaign to different people in our
network (with different demographics)
before launch, asking for feedback? It made
so much sense that I don’t know why I
hadn’t thought of it before (though I always
sent campaigns to my mom!). But now we
do an informal market research phase for
our projects, sending campaign details out
to a handful of trusted people, weeks in
advance. The feedback we get is invaluable,
and we use it to fine-tune every aspect of
our campaign so it can be optimized for its
audience. Reach out to people in your own
network who would be willing to take 30
minutes to provide fresh insight. You’ll have
a better idea of how different people
perceive and react to your message, and
you can tailor it from there.
The Didion Doc campaign really revolutionized the
way we approach getting people involved, especially
influencers. While Joan Didion clearly turned out to be
a bigger icon with more fans than we realized, these
strategies can be applied to all kinds of campaigns.
Give it a go.

Chapter 9
What’s Next for You, Me, and
Crowdfunding
For a long time, my job as the Crowdsourceress
meant that I worked intensely on preparing campaigns
for success. Most of my long hours, strategizing, and
planning happened before and during a campaign, up
until the very last day. I still do that. But more and
more, my clients and I are looking at a bigger picture.
A crowdfunding campaign is just a moment (a big
moment) in the much longer life of a brand, business,
or idea. Increasingly, my work also focuses on what
comes next: the aftermath of a crowdfunding
campaign.
We’ve covered a lot about preparing for rewards
fulfillment, figuring out the logistics, thanking backers
and journalists, and, of course, doing the work you
raised the money to do. But now, let’s think bigger.

FIRST: YOU CAN KEEP RAISING MONEY
So your campaign is over. You killed it! Awesome.
What’s next? I have talked about how the flow of
funding for most crowdfunding campaigns tends to
follow an inverse bell curve, where most funds come
in at the very beginning and very end of a campaign,
when there’s the most energy, momentum, and
urgency. The uptick in funding as a campaign nears its
end date is amazing—it can mean you get the final
push to meet your funding goal just in the nick of
time, or, even if you already met your goal, the extra
cash can go to anything from product enhancements
to speeding up the editing for your film, to pushing up
the delivery date of your rewards, to plenty of other
benefits for both you and your backers.
But, at some point, the campaign does finish. When
time’s up, that’s it. No more pledges can come
through. This can feel like a loss to creators, who
might still be seeing a ton of traffic on the campaign
page at the end. Sometimes, emails come in saying
things like “I missed your campaign! How can I get
this?” Many creators wonder how they can capitalize
on an interested audience once time’s up. Well,
crowdfunding platforms and savvy creators have
caught on to this and have developed great ways to
do just that. Here are a few that my clients and I have
tried so far.

INDIEGOGO INDEMAND
In January 2015, Indiegogo introduced InDemand, a
program that allows campaign owners to keep funding
after their campaign is over. It’s available for any
successfully funded campaign, even those that
originally ran on other platforms, such as Kickstarter.
With InDemand, creators can continue raising money
without setting a new fundraising goal or a deadline.
It’s almost as if the platform allows you to shift your
campaign from a one-time crowdfunding event to an
ongoing web shop. Creators have collectively raised
millions with InDemand. Some of the big success
stories are a drone that brought in another $1.3
million-plus after the campaign was over and a
connected carry-on suitcase campaign that raised an
additional $800,000-plus. It’s a powerful tool.
We’ve had a couple clients find success with
InDemand. We managed the relaunch of Aftermaster
Pro, the world’s first personal remastering device
(which improves the sound of audio content on your
TV and devices) on the platform. Aftermaster Pro
initially launched on Kickstarter and raised more than
$315,000. Then the Aftermaster team moved the
product to InDemand. That’s where we came in.
In many ways, we treated the move to InDemand
just like the launch of a regular crowdfunding
campaign. We helped coordinate a redesign of
Aftermaster’s website, campaign page, video, and
even the product itself. We worked on a digital media

campaign, coordinated with their press team, pitched
more than 500 influencers, and oversaw their social
media campaign. The strategy paid off: Aftermaster
has raised an additional $470,000 and counting
through InDemand.

KICKSTARTER SPOTLIGHT
Kickstarter also has a post–successful campaign tool,
called Spotlight, where creators can change their
campaign page to more of a landing page that tells
their post-campaign story. Once a campaign is
complete, creators can upload a large banner image
and post updates that appear in a detailed timeline.
The “Back This Project” button can be updated to
direct new visitors to a creator’s website, where
people can learn more about the project or business,
sign up for a mailing list, or—hopefully—make an
order. As if you don’t have enough stuff to do during
the campaign, it’s ideal to have a website with an
online store ready right when the campaign is over, so
visitors have a place to go to if they missed the
campaign. Still, be mindful of what you promised your
crowdfunding backers. If you said, for example, the
reward levels will be exclusive to the crowdfunding
campaign, the post-campaign website should have
higher price points.
After the Standards Manual campaigns, Hamish and
Jesse took advantage of the Spotlight feature by using
it to direct people to their own online store, which
they created with Shopify, an e-commerce platform.
For the NYCTA manual, they worked out a new
agreement with the MTA that allowed them to sell a
smaller, compact version of the book without the
essay and some of the fancy production values. (The
full-size edition was exclusive to the Kickstarter

campaign.) For NASA, they continued selling the full-
size book. They worked with the same printer and
fulfillment house used for the campaign. With the
launch of their website, people could go there directly
or through Spotlight, order one of the books, and have
it shipped to their doorstep.
Hamish and Jesse worked hard to drive attention to
their website when it launched, especially since there
was a gap between the end of the campaigns and the
launch of the online store. A big part of their effort
included investing in digital marketing and securing
press to drive more traffic. Vanity Fair wrote a
wonderful piece after their site launch titled “Meet the
Guys Turning Old Graphic Design Manuals into
Kickstarter Blockbusters.” It explained how “Now
[Hamish] Smyth and [Jesse] Reed are running a niche,
high-end publishing company. The pair have
discovered that you don’t necessarily need advertisers
or a book advance or a high-profile agent (though all of
those continue to be valuable) to make a successful
and in-demand product in 2016. You need passion, a
camera, and a computer. You need the right mix of a
website like Kickstarter, and an app like Shopify.”

BACKERKIT
Another way clients and I have kept funds coming in
after a campaign is through a third-party site called
BackerKit, a platform that allows creators to offer
surveys, collect data, and continue to take pre-orders
after a campaign ends.
Hamish and I used BackerKit in the summer of 2015
for our NYC Subway poster campaign. At the time we
launched, I had managed plenty of crowdfunding
campaigns for clients, but I hadn’t ever been a creator,
so it was a fun experiment for me to step into that
role and try out my campaign strategies on a project of
my own.
We set a goal of $29,800, but then we earned
nearly double that within a day (and ended up raising
over $172,000). Even though we were using vendors
to print and ship the posters, the fulfillment process
was still going to require a massive effort. There were
two versions of the poster to ship, plus a silkscreen
version we introduced midway through the campaign
(coming from a separate printer). Some of the posters
were going to be hand-signed and numbered by
Hamish before being sent out, too. On top of all that,
toward the end of the campaign, Hamish thought we
should offer the option for backers to frame their
prints. We wanted backers to be able to order a ready-
to-hang, framed item.
We checked out BackerKit because it offered an
add-on store, which would allow backers to add a

frame to their pledge. We also learned we could use
the site to sell additional posters after the campaign.
We set it up, and, as a result, we were able to get
more posters in the hands of backers—some framed
—and raised about $50,000 post-campaign.
Whichever method you use to continue sales after
your crowdfunding campaign, I always advise clients
to be respectful of their original pool of backers.
Without them, there wouldn’t be an opportunity to
continue funding or selling in the first place. Making
sure they get their rewards first should be your top
priority.

NEXT: CONTINUE TO BUILD MOMENTUM
Finding a way to capture that rush of visitor traffic to
your page at the end of a campaign is an important
thing to consider, but it’s also just a piece of a much
bigger picture. By now, this book should have drilled
into you that crowdfunding is community building.
When your campaign ends, you’ll have an audience of
supporters who backed, tweeted, talked about,
promoted, and cheered on your project. Not only have
you just funded your project—a huge accomplishment
—but you have also created a community of people
around it.
What are you going to do with that?
The sales tools I mentioned are great for capturing
that end-of-campaign traffic, but they’re also powerful
launch pads to use as you grow and expand your idea,
business, and brand well into the future. Because the
fun doesn’t have to stop when your campaign ends, or
even the week or month or year after your campaign
ends.
After a successful campaign, as a creator, you’ll go
on to make something, whether it’s a film or a bike or
a robotic arm. Even if you’ve raised funds for a one-
time need, like completing a documentary, there will
be more to do later: submitting your film to contests,
getting into film festivals, planning a launch party,
getting a publicist for movie reviews, and on and on.
Once your product is out in the world, you need to

consider how you’ll gather your audience around it,
generate buzz, and continue to grow. To make the
most of it, you need to develop a strategic plan to
continue maintaining, building, and growing your
community well beyond the crowdfunding campaign.
Hamish and Jesse—with their beautiful website,
press, social media presence, marketing strategy, and
ongoing sales—are a great example of what’s
possible: they’re now running a business. As you’ve
surely gathered from this book, it’s a lot of work to
ensure that a story resonates with people online, and
that challenge continues throughout all phases of a
project, long after crowdfunding. But here’s the real
secret: not only can you continue making sales after
your campaign ends, you can recycle everything you
learned in this book to grow and maintain your
relationship with your crowd.
At Vann Alexandra, we’ve started to call this
relationship building process “crowd relations.” It’s a
service we’re now offering, and it started because we
had clients come back to us after their campaign was
over asking for us to handle their PR. Our clients have
realized the importance of keeping attention on their
product after a crowdfunding campaign is complete—
especially when it’s ready to ship and becomes
available for purchase online. We’re now using our
expertise with crowds to offer a new kind of public
relations that’s more extensive and well-rounded—
one that includes email marketing, connecting with
press and influencers, strategy creation, branding, and
more. We don’t just want to get press for our clients.

We want that press to inspire their audience to take
action. We hope to take PR to the next level with
“CR.”

THE RAPID GROWTH—AND INCLUSIVITY—OF THE
CROWDFUNDING INDUSTRY
I ran my first campaign, for the film Sex and
Broadcasting, in 2012 and—I’m guessing just like so
many other creators on the platform at the time—I
knew next to nothing. Even as I launched my second
and third campaigns, I still felt like I was running
around in the dark, trying to cling to strategies that
worked and throwing out ones that didn’t.
Less than two years after I helped raise $80,000 for
Sex and Broadcasting, I helped smash an $800,000
goal within 24 hours for Neil Young’s PonoPlayer
campaign. It was clear that this wasn’t just my
personal experience; crowdfunding was a fast-moving
financial movement. As I write this in 2016, more than
$1 billion has been raised on Indiegogo, and about
$2.8 billion has been pledged to Kickstarter projects.
The growth across the crowdfunding space is almost
unbelievable.
I spoke with Evan Cohen, the former senior director
of design, technology, and hardware at Indiegogo,
about how crowdfunding has changed since its
inception. Evan explained how he thinks about the
evolution of crowdfunding in two stages: In the early
era of crowdfunding, between 2008 and 2013, most
campaigns were run by one person or a small team
that needed to raise money to take a project from
point A to point B; they needed a little money to keep
something going—to finish editing a film, for example.
“But around late 2012 and early 2013,” Evan said,

“We started seeing more established companies—
maybe people who had raised seed money or already
had money in the bank—use crowdfunding for a
different purpose, like for marketing, branding, and to
go to market. People were investing tens of
thousands of dollars into building a campaign, hiring
PR firms, digital marketing agencies, and branding
agencies.”
Evan’s right; I’ve seen it happen with my clients.
However, though crowdfunding is certainly becoming
more sophisticated and expansive, it’s not shutting
people out. Even on big sites like Indiegogo and
Kickstarter, there’s a broad diversity of projects, small
and large. As time goes on, I’m able to take on bigger
clients and campaigns—and in order to support my
growing team and to run my business, I need to.
Many of our campaigns now are product driven; the
likelihood of hitting bigger funding goals tends to be
higher, I’ve found, when people get a concrete reward
at the end of the campaign (the product itself). But
those aren’t the only campaigns out there.
Crowdfunding remains a democratic and inclusive
space, which is what I love about it.
There are now plenty of industry-specific platforms
where creators can take advantage of crowdfunding in
a community and environment that meets their needs
(sites dedicated to crowdfunding for music or for
games, for example). “We’re seeing the crowdfunding
ecosystem evolve and stratify—different platforms
provide different things,” Justin Kazmark, VP of
communications at Kickstarter told me. “Kickstarter is

leveling the creative playing field and allowing for
more imaginative and ambitious ideas to develop.”
I find it so exciting that crowdfunding is providing
incredible benefits for creators who may not
otherwise have had access to them. “Crowdfunding is
probably the most efficient and effective go-to-market
strategy because you get benefits beyond money,”
Evan said. “You’re going directly to consumers, so
you don’t have a middleman taking a fee and
percentage of retail. Crowdfunding provides a ton of
organic press opportunities and a ton of organic
sharing.… The concept of crowdfunding itself is driven
by social shares and virality, and that means you have
a potential to reach a much bigger audience.”
That potential provides massive opportunity for
those prepared to seize it. Take, for instance, the way
women entrepreneurs have been able to capitalize on
crowdfunding. “It’s no secret that women
entrepreneurs have an even harder time raising capital
from angels, venture capitalists and bankers than their
male counterparts,” states a recent article from
Forbes titled “Crowdfunding Is a Female Founder’s
Best Friend.” “But here’s the interesting news:
women outperform men when raising money for their
companies through rewards-based crowdfunding. That
means their products and services are hitting a
market.” As a young woman who started her
business from scratch—and is intimately familiar with
how challenging it can be—this is one of the aspects
of crowdfunding that keeps me coming back.
Crowdfunding as an industry has provided so much

for so many—myself included. It’s hard to say exactly
how crowdfunding will evolve in the future, but what’s
clear is that it’s doing incredible things for all kinds of
people and communities. It’s also changing so rapidly
that it challenges me to constantly be looking ahead.
Each campaign I run offers an opportunity for me to
push myself and to try something new—an idea,
strategy, or tactic. Nothing is ever guaranteed. But the
best way to learn—for me and for anyone who wants
to crowdfund—is to try. That’s what crowdfunding
demands of us. We’ve got to be informed, stay
focused, plan like crazy, give it our all, and then go for
it.

WHAT KEEPS ME COMING BACK
Some months ago, I had dinner with my college
philosophy professor who has been a mentor to me as
I’ve forged my career path—the same professor who
helped me when I was going through my early
twenties existential meltdowns. As we were catching
up, he challenged me to think about why I chose my
career in crowdfunding.
“In some ways, it just happened,” I explained to
him. “I never turned down work. I kept taking on
clients, and at some point, I started feeling like I
actually knew what I was doing.”
On the other hand, I know that it was more than
just happenstance and momentum. What inspires me
about this work is that it allows me to help and
connect with people trying to bring their projects into
the world. Helping creators is what has driven me all
along.
But I know my services aren’t accessible to
everyone. I wrote this book so I could give you access
to everything I’ve learned, sharing the same strategies
I use for all of my clients.
I’m so grateful I ended up in the crowdfunding
world at this exciting moment in its evolution. Seeing
the industry grow, and growing along with it, has been
a whirlwind. Whatever happens next, I want to keep
helping people with big ideas and big dreams. I hope
you’ll take what you’ve learned in this book and apply
it to your own big ideas and dreams, too. I know you
can.

Afterword
Becoming a Startup Founder
At the end of Neil Young’s PonoPlayer campaign,
back in the spring of 2014, I was on a huge high, but I
also had this nagging question: Now what?
Some of you might find yourselves with a similar
feeling in the weeks and months after your
crowdfunding campaign. And, what I ended up doing
—starting a business—might be what you do, too. A
recent study at the University of Pennsylvania’s
Wharton School showed that 19 percent of creators
have said they found a new job because of their
Kickstarter campaign. To take this further: Kickstarter
projects have created 29,600 full-time jobs and
283,000 part-time roles. Those are some pretty
exciting numbers.
There’s a chance some of you will find yourselves
with a new job or a business to run after your
campaign, so I don’t want to close this book without
sharing some of the most valuable things I’ve learned
on my own startup journey. Because, well, it wasn’t
always pretty. I had no background in marketing,
business, or finance. I was a philosophy major! But
there’s a lot I figured out along the way.

HOW TO MAKE IT A REAL THING
After the PonoPlayer campaign, my freelancer life
blew up in a big way. I’d been working from home on
crowdfunding campaigns, doing other gigs in film
production here and there, rolling with opportunities
as they came up. Then I got to work with Neil Young.
All of a sudden, calls from prospective clients, and the
media, were coming in left and right. People wanted
to talk to me and work with me. It was humbling and
so exciting.
I knew that it was time to jump in with both feet,
and I decided to make it official. With some of the
money I earned from the PonoPlayer campaign, I
incorporated Vann Alexandra and opened a business
bank account. (My full name is Vann Alexandra Daly. I
go by Alex, but I thought my first and middle names
sounded kind of cool together.) Around that time, I
knew I needed a company website, so I hired a
designer to build one. I rented a shared office space
nearby so I could get out of my kitchen, and I hired a
freelancer so I could take on more work. I didn’t know
where this road would take me, but I was ready to
give it a go. That’s when I really became not just the
Crowdsourceress, but also the proud founder of a
brand-new startup.
Starting Vann Alexandra, I certainly wasn’t sure
what I was doing, but I took my time, was shameless
about asking for advice, and never stopped hustling. I

didn’t have a proper business plan then, but I was
really conservative with finances. I didn’t seek
investment, mainly because I didn’t know where to
start, and more importantly, I didn’t want to have to
learn to run before I could walk. I grew the business
organically as projects came in. When I had a positive
cash flow and a pipeline full of projects, I knew I could
afford to hire someone and take on more work.

INVEST IN A LAWYER AND PUBLICITY
One of the most valuable things I did early on was find
the right lawyer. When you’re making any kind of
transaction—even if it’s a small amount of money or
between friends—you need a contract, and to have a
strong contract, you need a lawyer. Lawyers are
notoriously expensive. But I got connected with a law
firm that helps startups, and I asked them to help me
build contracts that I could customize in the future:
one for team members and one for clients. My lawyer
also advised me that if I could continue to own 100
percent of my company, I should. If you have enough
money to run your business, he advised, don’t give up
equity. It was great advice that I still follow today.
Maintaining ownership of my company is one of the
things I’m most proud of. As hard as it is, I absolutely
love the freedom of being able to make decisions
independently and do my own thing. (A note: This
worked great for my business, which is services
focused, but that wouldn’t be the case for everyone.
Some startups require a ton of capital to get started. If
that’s your situation, look for a lawyer who works with
startups that need capital.)
Earlier on, we also got support from a publicist who
helped lock in press and spread the word about the
work we were doing. I think it’s great to bring on this
kind of support when you launch—whether it’s a
publicist or digital marketer—in order to get traction in

the post-crowdfunding phase (when your product
starts shipping, for example). Luckily, we learned how
to do the press stuff ourselves, so now we do all our
own publicity in-house.

FIND AWESOME ADVISORS
Although I own 100 percent of my business, there is
no way I could make all of the decisions alone. Having
the counsel of trusted mentors who have more
experience than I do is so important. In my case, I’ve
been really fortunate to be able to lean on my parents
for guidance, especially in the beginning. My mom and
dad, both seasoned entrepreneurs, were a phone call
away whenever I felt like I was in over my head
(which was often). They were the ones who said,
“Never turn down new business. You can always find
help,” and countless other words of wisdom. Their
unconditional support has been beyond valuable to
me.
If, like me, you don’t have an MBA or any prior
business experience, then either seeking out mentors
or reading up is a must. Educate yourself. Don’t be
afraid to ask questions—if you’re too worried about
appearing inexperienced, you could miss out on vital
information. Recently, after turning to my parents and
trusted friends, I decided to get actual advisors—
people in the field that I could talk to about my
business model, clients, pricing, projects, and many
other things. It really helps to have an outside opinion
coming from those who are wiser than you in your
industry. Seek out these people and ask all the
questions.
Even with great support, running Vann Alexandra

has been a constant exercise in figuring it all out as I
go along, from managing clients to negotiating
contracts to understanding taxes and much, much
more. There have been plenty of bumps along the
way, and at the beginning I was a deer caught in the
headlights. After my DIY approach to taxes in 2014, I
learned how to get smart for the next year. I put
myself on the payroll and carefully kept track of
deductions. When I brought on employees, I put them
on salary and created an employee handbook. (I
Googled this and made it my own.) I stopped
managing accounts manually and started using
QuickBooks. I hired my accountant as an ongoing
advisor, and she’s been an incredible resource. I also
now use a site that handles all my payroll, HR, and W-
9s. It’s really helpful.

REMEMBER: FIRST IMPRESSIONS COUNT
One of the biggest lessons I’ve learned from running
my own business is that appearances are important. I
met Hamish right around the time I was starting Vann
Alexandra, and he was quick to tell me that my new
website wasn’t actually that great. He redesigned it
for me, then encouraged me to think about other
assets I needed: business cards, a proposal template,
and a client kit introducing our company and what we
do.
And it’s not just aesthetics. How you communicate
with clients and everyone around you is vital. I
remember during the first summer we were dating,
Hamish had a day off from work and he came to my
office to help out. He looked at what I drafted for our
client kit and then I watched as he crossed out
sentence after sentence. “Cut all this out,” he said.
“These buzzwords don’t mean anything.” (I was using
words like “curate” a lot.) He told me about the book
Writing That Works: How to Communicate Effectively
in Business by Kenneth Roman and Joel Raphaelson. I
got a copy, and it completely revolutionized how I
write and communicate with clients. Now, I keep
emails and pitches to a few sentences. I make sure
campaign pages are easy to understand. I focus on
saying what I mean clearly and directly, avoiding
jargon. (Yes, I know I use the word “influencers” a ton
in this book. Sometimes industry terminology is
unavoidable.)

GET PAID
Learning to price my work took time. In the very
beginning, I sort of winged it based on past
experience. But I quickly realized that it made more
sense to work on a commission, where I earned part
of the total amount I helped my clients crowdfund.
With time, I started working on more extensive
projects, hitting higher goals for bigger projects. I
began asking for a retainer up front, along with a
commission based on the final goal and the scope of
the work my team would be doing. Now I mostly work
on retainer with a bonus fee structure.
It’s so hard to raise your rates. I have found that,
especially as a woman, it’s tough to speak up. For a
long time, I suffered from imposter syndrome where
you think that your success is just luck or an accident,
not the result of your knowledge and abilities. That
made it tough for me to ask for more money. But you
need to believe that you are valuable. We recently
raised our rates, and I learned to gauge how people
react. Hamish gave me this great piece of advice,
paraphrased from an article by designer Jessica
Hische: If clients accept your rates immediately, you
should have charged more. If they negotiate, often
you can work out the right price. And if they say the
quote is too high, you can decide if you should work
within their budget, or walk away. (Another thing I
have learned is if clients totally have sticker shock,
then you’re charging too much.)

MISTAKES AND FAILURE: LEARN AND MOVE
FORWARD
Recently, I ran a crowdfunding campaign that didn’t
meet its goal. Despite our best efforts, the project
never gained traction. On top of that, it even got
criticized and received a lot of negative commentary
online. When it failed, I lost the 100 percent success
rate I’d publicly maintained throughout my
crowdfunding career. I had to face the reality that
keeping up that success rate wasn’t sustainable.
Nobody can bat a thousand, and there’s no such thing
as perfection in crowdfunding or business (or anything
in life). In the end, what I was proud of is that I stood
by my client’s side all the way to the day the
campaign officially failed. I learned that success
doesn’t come just from projects that make money; it
comes from working on projects I believe in and
maintaining loyalty to the clients I have the privilege of
working with.
A big lesson in running a startup is learning how to
recover from rough times, too. Very occasionally we
work with a client who’s not a great fit for us. I won’t
go into too much detail here, but after trying and
failing to find ways to collaborate with a particular
client, we had to part ways and it felt terrible. But I
knew my team and I needed to stay positive and
move forward right away. Together we made
margaritas in the office and said “cheers” to the next
project, which we worked on twice as hard.

BE A TEAM PLAYER
One of my favorite parts of running a business is
having amazing people to work alongside. It feels so
reassuring and empowering to know that it’s not just
me who’s invested in this work; I have a team who’s
invested, too.
It’s incredible knowing my team is with me along
the way, especially because one of the hardest things
about the startup world is dealing with turnover. It’s a
huge challenge to find the right fit, and training new
hires is a big investment.
So I’ve also had to learn how to effectively manage
people, create structure, and bring out the best in
everybody. In the beginning, I remember a day where
I got really frustrated with one of my staff members
after catching a series of mistakes. I expected him/her
to know everything from how to talk to a client to how
to format an email. Then I realized I was being
impatient and unrealistic. We’re a small business, and
we don’t have a formal training program; everyone is
learning on the job and doing their best. But I could
also do more to support my team and to formalize and
teach standard processes. That’s when I created our
employee handbook, which details everything from
how we run campaigns to how to log vacation time.
Now, we have weekly team meetings. Also, at the
end of each day we email each other what we plan to
work on the following day—what we call “priority

objectives”—so that everyone’s on the same page.
It’s important to have a standard way for everyone to
know what we’re all up to. We also use an app called
Slack to chat during the day about everything from
projects to what we’re ordering for lunch.
Managing my team has taught me how to be a
positive leader. I try to lead by example—and I always
tell my teammates not to apologize when they make a
mistake. There’s nothing to be sorry about; I just want
to know that they’ve learned from it.
And then there are client relationships.
Crowdfunding is stressful, and part of our job is
helping clients navigate through that stress—while
trying not to become stressed ourselves. I really care
about what I do, and when I work on a new campaign,
I treat it like my own project. That’s part of what I love
about my job: I’m good at connecting with people and
their passions on an emotional level. But sometimes I
worry that I care too much about the work, and it can
really take a toll on me. At one point, after a string of
tough campaigns and clients, and suffering from
serious burnout, I had to take a step back and evaluate
what was working and what wasn’t working.
Sometimes you just have to tell yourself you’re not
saving lives and remind yourself that this is a job.
As a business owner, I face a lot of the same
challenges anyone else does in trying to earn a living,
make a difference, and feel happy and balanced at the
end of the day. I’m often under a lot of pressure, and
I’m always worried about something, but it’s worth it.
It took a weird, winding path for me to get to where I

am today, but I wouldn’t change a thing. If I could go
back in time to when I was just starting out, I’d do it
all again.
My final words? I believe in you. Now, go make
something amazing.

CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN CALENDAR
Here’s a suggested timeline to help you prepare for
your campaign launch. There’s also a sample Launch
Day schedule and some tips for what to do during and
after your campaign. Every timeline will be different,
of course. There have been campaigns where we had
to accelerate the launch and didn’t put the campaign
page together until less than a week before. There
have also been times when the video wasn’t
completely finalized until minutes to launch (scary!).
This schedule is fairly conservative and is meant to be
a guide to help you get started, so it’s not a
prescription for exactly how things need to be done.
You might cross some things off your list earlier or
later. That’s okay!

UP TO 6 MONTHS BEFORE LAUNCH
• Assess your audience. Do you have a built-in
audience that’s shown interest in your idea?
• Set up a website or landing page for your
project, product, or business. Your key call-
to-action should be an invitation to sign up
for your mailing list.
• Set up social media accounts for your
project, product, or business. Share and
engage.
• Consider doing digital marketing for email
capture, hiring a designer, and/or sending
pre-campaign market research surveys
(especially for product and tech campaigns).
• Research the competition. Review similar
campaigns and press. Continue learning
about your audience.
• Back other projects.

8 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Set up your account and start your profile
and page for your crowdfunding campaign.
• Create an outline for your campaign page.
• Create a rewards wish list. Research
logistics to refine your list. Check platform
rules and resources.
• Get in touch with fulfillment partners and
look into production and shipping costs.
• Start a budget worksheet and begin tallying
costs.
• Conceptualize your video. Write a script, get
feedback on it, and finalize. Assemble your
video team.
Social media
• Start growing your followings on your social
media accounts organically and/or through
digital marketing strategies.
• Identify potential influencers and begin
compiling them in a spreadsheet.
• Continue building your mailing list.
Aggregate all your team’s contacts. Ensure
people are signing up through your website.
Incentivize them with a giveaway or with
the promise they’ll be the first to know

when your product is available or your
campaign goes live.
Press
• Research recent press related to your
industry or campaign to identify trends,
fresh angles for your pitches, and reporters
who could be interested in your campaign.

6 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Update your budget based on the rewards
list.
• Write the first full draft for your campaign
page.
• Shoot your video and begin preparing a first
cut.
Social media
• Continue being active across social media
platforms.
• Continue adding to your influencer database.
• Continue building your mailing list. Use an
email marketing service, like MailChimp, and
upload all your contacts to it.
Press
• Continue building your press database.

4 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Fine-tune and finalize your budget.
• Get feedback on your campaign page first
draft and refine. Add photos, graphics, and
other visual material to your story.
• Review the first cut of your video. Collect
and provide feedback to the video team.
Social media
• Begin telling everyone you know about your
campaign. You are launching in a month!
• Develop a social media plan with campaign-
specific tweets and content (videos, images,
and graphics), and possible influencer
takeovers or giveaways.
• Finalize your influencer list and create a
customizable pitch template. You will begin
pitching in a week!
• Continue building your mailing list and
uploading the new contacts to your email
service.
• Continue digital marketing strategies.
Press
• Polish up your press database.
• Draft your press kit.

3 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Write, get feedback on, and strengthen the
rewards copy.
• Draft potential updates to send to backers
during the campaign.
• Receive the next cut of the video and
provide feedback.
• Create appropriate graphics or hi-res photos
of rewards as needed.
• Talk to a developer about adding a campaign
widget or button to your company website
that links to the campaign when it’s live.
Social media
• Create sample tweets and Facebook posts
for influencers to share.
• Begin pitching influencers.
• Continue building your mailing list and
importing contacts to your email service.
Press
• Finalize the press kit. Get your press release
designed.
• Finalize press database. You will begin
pitching next week!

2 WEEKS BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Confirm that your budget is set.
• Finalize the campaign page copy.
• Receive the final cut of your video and
approve or make small, final edits.
• Continue preparing engaging updates that
you can send to your backers.
Social media
• Continue pitching influencers.
• Line up tweets and posts for the first one to
two weeks of your campaign.
• Draft emails for your family, friends, and
close network asking for early Launch Day
pledges.
Press
• Begin pitching press.

1 WEEK BEFORE LAUNCH
Campaign
• Aim to have 20 percent of your total funding
goal locked in from your personal networks
the morning of your campaign. It’s ok if you
can’t reach this amount, but do have early
donations secured.
• Make sure your video, graphics, rewards,
and entire campaign page is final. Proofread
everything one last time.
• Think of anything you missed. For example,
a backer may need to pay duties and taxes.
Post this information in a place where
backers can see it.
• If you anticipate your audience will have
questions about your project, pre-write your
FAQs to upload on Launch Day.
• Submit your project for approval (for
Kickstarter) about 1 week before your
launch date.
Social media
• Continue pitching influencers.
• Send 1-week announcement email asking
for Launch Day support.
• Send a day-before email to the same group
reminding them you go live in the morning.

• Prepare a final email for the morning of your
launch.
Press
• Continue pitching press. Try to get all the
press lined up for Launch Day.

FINAL CHECKLIST
• Reread the platform rules.
• Check that your launch date and end date
are correct in all campaign materials and that
your reward delivery dates and domestic
and international shipping costs are correct,
too.
• Watch your video all the way through and
upload it again if you notice any playback
problems.
• Reread your campaign page and rewards
descriptions to confirm that your platform
saved your edits.
• Double-check everything you won’t be able
to change once your project is live.

LAUNCH DAY SAMPLE SCHEDULE
8:00 AM EST
• Click “launch”!
• Email your colleagues, family, and friends
with your campaign link for early donations.
9:00 AM EST
• Once you have donations on the page, email
the journalist for your exclusive so they can
run the piece with your campaign link.
• Add a campaign link or widget to pledge on
your website.
9:30 AM EST
• Once the exclusive is live, alert any other
journalists that you have locked articles with
and send them the campaign link.
• Post a social media graphic with the
campaign link announcing the launch.
• Post FAQs.
10:00 AM EST
• Email social media influencers with the
campaign link and sample tweets/posts to
share on social media.
11:00 AM EST
• Send the press release to press contacts

who didn’t respond to your earlier pitch. Be
sure your page has traction before you do
this.
All Day
• Be active on social media.
• Continue pitching influencers and press.
• Keep an eye out for any questions that
come up on social media or in the campaign
comments and respond to them. Add them
to the FAQ section of your page if
necessary.

RUNNING THE CAMPAIGN
What to stay on top of
• Make sure you’re updating written and
visual material on your project page as the
campaign evolves. This includes posting
campaign updates, adding press links to the
page, coming up with new rewards, and
handling inbound communications from
backers.
• Continue to be active on social media,
sharing updates and press about your
project. This means connecting with
influencers, discussing potential cross-
promotions, and creating partnerships and
collaborations with supportive influencers.
• Consider a new digital marketing campaign.
• Keep identifying new press markets. Pitch
other publications and blogs about your
project and its developments.
• Create ideas for potential giveaways,
promotional campaigns, and events that will
drive traffic to your project.
• Keep track of how your campaign is doing
overall. If it looks like you’ll reach your goal
(or if you already have), decide whether you
want to continue raising money when time’s

up.
• If you reach the goal before the campaign
ends, let backers know where the extra
money is going and think about stretch
goals.
Final week of the campaign
• Continue the items under “What to stay on
top of” (just above).
• Reconnect with press and influencers to
announce the end of your campaign.
• Reconnect with personal networks
reminding them to pledge, if they haven’t
already.
• Post an update to encourage backers to
continue spreading the word in the final
days.
Final day of the campaign
• Post a final-day update for your backers.
• Announce the end of your campaign on
social media.
• On Kickstarter, the page freezes when the
campaign ends, so make any necessary
changes before it does.

AFTER THE CAMPAIGN WRAPS
Have a drink. Then get back to work!
• Post your “Thank You” update on the
campaign page and on all your social media
channels. This can be creative and can
include a video, GIF, or just a thoughtful
note. Thank the journalists who covered
your campaign—personally, in updates, and
with shout-outs on social media.
• Afterward, make sure you respond to
inbound communication from backers—their
comments, concerns, and feedback. Stay
active on social media!
• Make sure you follow up with backers
concerning payment issues, and consider
alternate payment methods for backers who
cannot or do not want to pay through the
campaign (PayPal or Google Wallet), so
backers can reconcile payments on
Kickstarter.
• Collect all your backers’ info. Indiegogo
collects shipping addresses at purchase, and
you can get rewards details like t-shirt sizes
via email; Kickstarter collects all this info
through their built-in survey. Export your
fulfillment data.

• Send the fulfillment information to your
shipping vendor if you’re using one.
• Ship your rewards and be diligent about
being on time!

BUDGET WORKSHEET
The most important part of a budget worksheet?
Having one! Start your worksheet early (use Excel or
another program with formulas), get feedback from
colleagues and an accountant, and double- and triple-
check that you’re not missing anything. As your
campaign launch approaches, you’ll be constantly
revisiting, adjusting, and fine-tuning it depending on
your product.
None of this is set in stone, but to help guide you,
I’ve put together a sample budget for a Kickstarter
project. All of these numbers are hypothetical, and
these costs can vary rather widely. I’ve seen
campaign videos made for under $2,000 and for over
$30,000. The point is to do the math and avoid
missing anything. This worksheet is the starting point
for thinking about the kinds of costs you’ll need to
consider.
